EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strengthening low pressure moved into the southern Great Lakes, crossing southern lower Michigan during the daylight hours of the 28th. This resulted in a significant winter storm for most of northern lower Michigan. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were common on the 28th. Snowfall totals were mostly in the 7 to 13 inch range, and the highest amounts of around 16 inches fell near Cadillac and Lake City. Winds increased toward the tail end of the storm, resulting in increasing blowing and drifting snow. Very cold air was in place before the storm arrived, and returned as the storm exited. Wind chills of 15 to 30 below zero were common in northern lower Michigan. Wind chills were much colder in eastern upper Michigan, including -51 at Kinross, and -42 at Sault Ste Marie and Mackinac Island.

A strong low pressure system reached Lower Michigan on January 28th.  Blizzard conditions were common from North Dakota to southern Wisconsin, with snow falling heavily in Lower Michigan on the 28th. Snowfall totals were generally from 4 to 10 inches, with a stripe of higher amounts along and north of Highway 10.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to eleven inches was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Deepening low pressure lifted across Iowa and Minnesota, passing west of Michigan. Moisture surged northward into northern Michigan on the 7th, ahead of the low. Precipitation started everywhere as snow, but in northern lower Michigan turned to sleet, freezing rain, and then rain. The heaviest wintry precipitation fell in eastern upper Michigan, almost all in the form of snow. Snowfall totals of 10 to 16 inches were common in northern and eastern Mackinac County, and all of Chippewa County. Drummond Island reached 18 inches.

Snowfall totals were generally from 4 to 10 inches, with a stripe of higher amounts along and north of Highway 10.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Seven to ten inches was reported.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve to as much as sixteen inches was reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved across Michigan from southwest to northeast on the 23rd. Wintry precipitation came in two waves. The first brought a few inches of snow to the area on the evening of the 22nd. Then, after a lull overnight, precipitation rates ramped up again during the day on the 23rd. Total snowfall amounts of 7 to 12 inches were common, over a fairly small portion of eastern upper and far northern lower Michigan. The highest amount, around 14 inches, fell near Royston in Montmorency County.

A deepening low pressure system through the Ohio Valley produced a swath of accumulating snow and strong winds across the Lower Great Lakes region on Saturday, January 19th. Snow totals of 6 to 10 inches and wind gusts to near 40 mph created difficult travel conditions.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate to at times heavy snow developed early on the 19th and continued through the late afternoon hours. Winds really pick up during the day, gusting between 25 and 35 mph during the afternoon. Snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 6 and 10 inches, with significant blowing and drifting reported due to the strong winds. Magician Lake received 8.0 of total snow accumulation. Slide-offs and accidents were reported across the region. A few secondary roads were impassable due to the significant drifting.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Alberta Clipper brought heavy snow and gusty winds to Lower Michigan January 28th into early January 29th. Snow accumulations generally ranged between 4 and 9 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread around daybreak on January 28th and continued through early January 29th. Some freezing drizzle did mix in during the late afternoon and evening hours. Total snow accumulations across the county ranged between 7 and 10 inches. A trained spotter 1 mile southwest of Fair Plain received 9.0 inches of snow. Gusty winds to near 30 mph led to considerable blowing and drifting snow which resulted in limited visibility and difficult travel. There were numerous school delays and cancellations, along with reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dangerous arctic air mass overspread Lower Michigan January 30th into the morning hours of January 31st. Wind chills between 25 and 40 degrees below zero were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusty west winds ushered in a bitterly cold arctic air mass on January 30th into the morning hours of January 31st. The coldest of the air and strongest winds occurred during the morning hours of January 30th when the wind chill value at Hillsdale dropped to 38 degrees below zero. Wind chills through the event generally ranged between 25 and 40 degrees below zero. The coldest air temperature recorded at Hillsdale was 18 degrees below zero on January 30th. Many businesses and schools were closed on both January 30th and January 31st due to this record breaking shot of dangerous cold air.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A dangerous arctic air mass overspread Lower Michigan January 30th into the morning hours of January 31st. Wind chills between 25 and 40 degrees below zero were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusty west winds ushered in a bitterly cold arctic air mass on January 30th into the morning hours of January 31st. The coldest of the air and strongest winds occurred during the morning hours of January 30th when the wind chill value at Coldwater dropped to 40 degrees below zero. Wind chills through the event generally ranged between 25 and 40 degrees below zero. The coldest air temperature recorded at Batavia was 19 degrees below zero on January 30th. Many businesses and schools were closed on both January 30th and January 31st due to this record breaking shot of dangerous cold air.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gusty west winds ushered in a bitterly cold arctic air mass on January 30th into the morning hours of January 31st. The coldest of the air and strongest winds occurred during the morning hours of January 30th when the wind chill value at Three Rivers dropped to 39 degrees below zero. Wind chills through the event generally ranged between 25 and 40 degrees below zero. The coldest air temperature recorded at Three Rivers was 19 degrees below zero on January 31st. Many businesses and schools were closed on both January 30th and January 31st due to this record breaking shot of dangerous cold air. Lake effect snow showers and blowing snow also helped wreak havoc on area roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Outflow boundaries from convection across central Lower Michigan and subtle shortwaves passing through the region caused thunderstorms to develop. High CAPE values but low shear allowed the storms to form quickly but struggle to organize. Eventually, greater DCAPE values arrive with one of the waves and caused more extensive wind damage in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fire officials reported multiple trees and power lines down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Outflow boundaries from convection across central Lower Michigan and subtle shortwaves passing through the region caused thunderstorms to develop. High CAPE values but low shear allowed the storms to form quickly but struggle to organize. Eventually, greater DCAPE values arrive with one of the waves and caused more extensive wind damage in a few locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local dispatch officials reported trees across the road. Also, power lines were reported down on Mason Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Pre frontal trough and remnant outflow boundaries allowed convection to develop. Instability was limited across southern Lower Michigan but shear was higher in these locations. Only isolated damage was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported multiple trees down in the area.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Pre frontal trough and remnant outflow boundaries allowed convection to develop. Instability was limited across southern Lower Michigan but shear was higher in these locations. Only isolated damage was reported.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported a tree was blown down in the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 75-year old man was found dead in an alleyway in Iron River on the morning of the 16th.  Police said that health and weather were contributing factors in the man's death.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Iron River Police Department received a call about an unresponsive man found in an alleyway on the morning of the 16th.  The 75-year old man was confirmed deceased once police and EMS arrived on the scene.  Law enforcement said that health and weather were contributing factors in the man's death.  Temperatures on the morning of the 16th were determined to be around 10 above zero, but wind chills were likely at or below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system over the western Great Lakes produced areas of moderate lake enhanced snow and light freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan on the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reports near Three Lakes reported moderate to heavy freezing drizzle causing slippery roads and ice accumulation on windshields. Around three inches of snow was also reported near Pelkie during the day on the 22nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system over the western Great Lakes produced areas of moderate lake enhanced snow and light freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan on the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An NWS employee from near National Mine observed light freezing drizzle along County Road 581 in south Ely Township.  The WJMN-TV meteorologist observed a light glaze of ice on vehicles and windshields in Marquette.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system over the western Great Lakes produced areas of moderate lake enhanced snow and light freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan on the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter in Copper Harbor estimated six inches of snow in approximately nine hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system over the western Great Lakes produced areas of moderate lake enhanced snow and light freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan on the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Redridge measured 7.5 inches of snow in approximately 15 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system over the western Great Lakes produced areas of moderate lake enhanced snow and light freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan on the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to six inches of lake enhanced snow was reported between McMillan and Newberry over a 12-hour time period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air pouring across the Upper Great Lakes produced bitter cold temperatures and wind chills from the 26th into the 31st.  On the 28th, Governor Whitmer declared a state of emergency to help address threats to public safety and respond to the extreme cold weather during the Arctic outbreak.  Whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also observed mainly across the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 27th into the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fine-flaked lake effect snow and blowing snow resulted in poor visibility across the county on the 27th.  The near whiteout conditions contributed to a multi-vehicle crash and pileup along the Seney Stretch of Highway M-28 on the early afternoon of the 27th.  A total of eight vehicles were damaged with numerous other vehicles going into the ditch to avoid collisions.  As a result, M-28 was closed for three hours between M-77 in Seney and M-94 in Shingleton.  A 67-year old man and two women, one 65-years old and the other 52-years old, received serious injuries in the crash.  All three people were transported to Helen Newberry Joy Hospital for treatment. ||Minimum wind chill values during the period were between 25 to 30 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air pouring across the Upper Great Lakes produced bitter cold temperatures and wind chills from the 26th into the 31st.  On the 28th, Governor Whitmer declared a state of emergency to help address threats to public safety and respond to the extreme cold weather during the Arctic outbreak.  Whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also observed mainly across the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 27th into the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Fine-flaked lake effect snow and blowing snow resulted in poor visibility and occasional whiteout conditions across the county on the 27th.  Minimum wind chill values during the period were from 25 to 30 below zero.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air pouring across the Upper Great Lakes produced bitter cold temperatures and wind chills from the 26th into the 31st.  On the 28th, Governor Whitmer declared a state of emergency to help address threats to public safety and respond to the extreme cold weather during the Arctic outbreak.  Whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also observed mainly across the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 27th into the 31st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing drizzle and freezing rain developed during the afternoon and early evening hours of January 22nd creating slick roads. Ice accretions of a glaze to one tenth of an inch were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and drizzle developed mid-afternoon on January 22nd and continued into the evening. Temperatures did warm above freezing into the morning of January 23rd while the rain continued, though sub-freezing road temperatures kept most secondary roads and sidewalks slick into January 23rd. There were numerous reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region. Many schools and businesses across the region were closed due to these icy road conditions.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing drizzle and freezing rain developed during the afternoon and early evening hours of January 22nd creating slick roads. Ice accretions of a glaze to one tenth of an inch were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain and drizzle developed mid-afternoon on January 22nd and continued into the evening. Temperatures did warm above freezing into the morning of January 23rd while the rain continued, though sub-freezing road temperatures kept most secondary roads and sidewalks slick into January 23rd. Many schools and businesses across the region were closed due to these icy road conditions. There were numerous reports of slide-offs and accidents across the region. There was one fatality with a car accident on US 12 Tuesday evening, January 22.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong Alberta Clipper brought heavy snow and gusty winds to Lower Michigan January 28th into early January 29th. Snow accumulations generally ranged between 4 and 9 inches.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow overspread around daybreak on January 28th and continued through early January 29th. Some freezing drizzle did mix in during the late afternoon and evening hours. Total snow accumulations across the county ranged between 4 and 6 inches. Gusty winds to near 30 mph led to considerable blowing and drifting snow which resulted in limited visibility and difficult travel. There were numerous school delays and cancellations, along with reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper-level low pressure system over the western Great Lakes produced areas of moderate lake enhanced snow and light freezing rain over portions of Upper Michigan on the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 4.3 inches of snow near Escanaba in 15 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated three to six inches of lake effect snow in the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 25th.  Wind chill values lowered into the 25 to 30 below zero range from the morning of the 25th through the morning of the 26th.  Area schools were closed on the 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer six miles north of Greenland measured eight inches of lake enhanced snow in 12-18 hours.  Northwest winds gusting to 30 mph also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and greatly reduced visibility at times.  Wind chill values also lowered into the 25 to 30 below zero range by the morning of the 25th.  Schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Newberry and Halfway Lake measured at least six inches of lake effect snow during the 18-hour period ending on the morning of the 25th. Wind chill values plummeted to nearly 30 below zero by the morning of the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Cusino Lake measured 14 inches of lake effect snow over a two-day period ending on the evening of the 25th.  Northwest wind gusting near 30 mph also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and greatly reduced visibility.  Wind chill values plummeted to 25 to 30 below zero by the morning of the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: This was one of relatively few periods of sustained heavy lake effect snow during the winter. Some of the coldest air of the winter thus far entered northern Michigan, initially on north to north-northwest winds. The lake effect snow initially focused near and west of Grand Traverse Bay during the day on the 24th. However, as winds backed late in the day, the snow pushed further inland into north central lower Michigan. Snowfall rates of around 2 inches per hour were common in the stronger bands. The highest snowfall amounts, 12 to 14 inches, fell near Mancelona and Elmira.

Arctic air pouring across the Upper Great Lakes produced bitter cold temperatures and wind chills from the 26th into the 31st.  On the 28th, Governor Whitmer declared a state of emergency to help address threats to public safety and respond to the extreme cold weather during the Arctic outbreak.  Whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also observed mainly across the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 27th into the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minimum wind chill values dipped into the 25 to 35 below range during the period.  Schools were closed most days between the 28th and the 31st due to the bitter cold.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lake snowfall totals reached as high as 12-14 inches at Wetmore and Au Train for the 24-hour period ending on the morning of the 30th.  Northwest winds frequently gusting to 35 mph or greater caused blizzard conditions in heavy snow and blowing snow throughout much of period.  Highway M-28 was closed by law enforcement from Munising to the Marquette County line on the afternoon of the 29th and remain closed into the morning of the 31st.  Schools were closed throughout the period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic air outbreak into the Midwest at the end of January 2019 brought extreme low temperatures and dangerous wind chills for several days. Numerous low temperature records were set across the area. The arctic front moved through Southeast Michigan on Tuesday, January 29 and temperatures fell to below zero by early Wednesday morning. In fact, the high temperatures for Wednesday in Detroit and Flint were recorded at midnight as temps remained below zero all day into Thursday. Detroit spent 36 consecutive hours below 0 - this was the longest such streak since Jan. 1994 (66 hours). Flint also spent 36 hours below 0. A tightened pressure gradient over the region and excellent mixing led to winds gusting over 35 mph at times from Tuesday night through Wednesday evening. The result was wind chills near or below -35 for numerous hours. Two deaths were attributed to the cold in Wayne County.

Warm, moist air lifting across the colder air mass in place produced moderate to heavy snow across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 6th into the 7th.  The wet, heavy snow caused most schools to close throughout the area on the 7th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer five miles northwest of Atlantic Mine measured eight inches of snow in 12 hours.  Houghton County Schools were closed on the 7th as a result of the wet, heavy snowfall.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air pouring across the Upper Great Lakes produced bitter cold temperatures and wind chills from the 26th into the 31st.  On the 28th, Governor Whitmer declared a state of emergency to help address threats to public safety and respond to the extreme cold weather during the Arctic outbreak.  Whiteout conditions in lake effect snow and blowing snow were also observed mainly across the west to northwest wind snow belts of Lake Superior from the 27th into the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Occasional whiteouts in heavy snow and blowing snow were reported by county law enforcement throughout the afternoon of the 29th into the morning of the 31st.  M-28 was closed due to the extreme blowing and drifting of snow over the road from northwest winds gusting to 35 mph.  Area schools remained closed throughout the period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: As an arctic air mass moved over the Midwest, lake effect snow increased over the eastern Lake Michigan shore and continued almost nonstop from January 29th to 31st. Normally a prolonged period of lake effect snow would lead to impressive snow totals, but the extremely cold air mass did not allow for efficient snowflake production.  Nonetheless, the small snowflakes combined with gusty winds lead to a prolonged period of low visibility to near-blizzard conditions, especially along and west of US-131.||The lake effect snow finally ended Thursday evening, leaving behind an additional 6 to 12 inches of snow.   The combination of falling snow, gusty winds, and light snow led to considerable blowing snow restricting visibilities across Lower Michigan for a prolonged period of time.  In many areas, visibility was at or below 3 miles for days in a row, with extended periods of at or below 1/4 of a mile.  There were hundreds of school closings during this period.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Six to twelve inches of lake effect snow fell.  This in conjunction with bitterly cold air and gusty winds that resulted in dangerously cold wind chills as cold as 20 to 40 below zero at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An arctic air outbreak into the Midwest at the end of January 2019 brought extreme low temperatures and dangerous wind chills for several days. Numerous low temperature records were set across the area. The arctic front moved through Southeast Michigan on Tuesday, January 29 and temperatures fell to below zero by early Wednesday morning. In fact, the high temperatures for Wednesday in Detroit and Flint were recorded at midnight as temps remained below zero all day into Thursday. Detroit spent 36 consecutive hours below 0 - this was the longest such streak since Jan. 1994 (66 hours). Flint also spent 36 hours below 0. A tightened pressure gradient over the region and excellent mixing led to winds gusting over 35 mph at times from Tuesday night through Wednesday evening. The result was wind chills near or below -35 for numerous hours. Two deaths were attributed to the cold in Wayne County.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of nearly eight inches of lake enhanced snow in Ironwood in ten hours.  Northwest winds gusting as high as 30 mph also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and greatly reduced visibility.  Wind chill values by the morning of the 25th dipped into the 30 to 35 below zero range.  Schools were closed on the 25th due to the bitter cold.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Painesdale and near Houghton measured between 10 and 12 inches of lake enhanced snow over a 24 hour period ending on the morning of the 25th.  Northwest winds gusting to 30 mph at times also caused blowing and drifting of snow.  Minimum wind chill values of 25 to 35 below zero were also reported from the morning of the 25th through much of the 26th.  Schools in Houghton County were closed on the 25th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 3-6 inches of lake effect snow fell in the 12-hour period ending on the evening of the 24th.  Strong west to northwest winds gusting to 35-45 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and occasional whiteout conditions from the 24th into the 25th.  Schools were closed on the 25th.  Wind chill values lowered into the 25 to 30 below zero range from the morning of the 25th through much of the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of 6.5 inches of snowfall in 24 hours just south of Baraga for the period ending on the morning of the 25th.  Six inches of snow also fell near Pelkie. Wind chill values dropped into the 25 to 30 below zero range from the morning of the 25th into the morning of the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall across the county ranged from two to locally five inches over an 18-hour period ending on the morning of the 25th.  Northwest winds gusting to 25 to 30 mph on the afternoon of the 24th also caused reduced visibility at times in blowing snow. ||Troopers from the MSP Negaunee post responded to a two-vehicle crash on US-41 near Brebner Road in Negaunee Township on the afternoon of the 24th.  The crash investigation determined that a 2004 Toyota Avalon driven by an 81-year cold male from Sands Township was eastbound on US-41 and while attempting a left turn drove into the path of a westbound 2006 Chevrolet Colorado pickup truck driven by a 57-year old from Champion.  A 78-year old female passenger in the Toyota Avalon was killed in the crash.  Both drivers were transported to UP Health Systems in Marquette for treatment of injuries.||In a separate incident, a Northern Michigan University student hiking and taking photographs in the Yellow Dog River near County Road 510 became disoriented in the snow and blowing snow that hit the area on the afternoon of the 24th.  Search crews looked for the male student for several days until his deceased body was located on the afternoon of the 27th just south of County Road 510. It was determined he died of exposure.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong low pressure tracked through southeast Michigan, leading to a wide range in snowfall amounts, with the least amounts south of I-94, and the highest amounts occurring north of I-69. Snowfall amounts ranged from around 2 inches in Monroe to 10 inches over Bay and Huron counties. In addition, strong northeast winds gusting between 25 to 35 mph coming of Lake Huron and Saginaw Bay lead to some blowing and drifting of the snow north of I-69 as well.  Here are some of the higher snowfall reports received:||Harbor Beach... 10 inches.|Bay City (4N)... 10 inches.|Bad Axe...   9 inches.|Cass City... 8 inches. |Lapeer...    8 inches. |Columbiaville... 8 inches.|Marlette... 7 inches.|Leonard... 6 inches.|Manchester... 5 inches.|Detroit Metro... 4 inches.

A strong cold front moving across the area generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 8th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were reports of seven inches of fluffy lake effect snow and blowing snow at Wakefield and Ironwood over an approximate 24-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across the area generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 8th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter four miles south of Mass City reported 14 inches of fluffy lake effect snow and blowing snow over a 24-hour period.  The spotter also reported that the VFW and East Branch roads were drifted shut from the snow.  Schools were delayed two hours across Ontonagon County on the 19th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minimum wind chill values throughout the period were in the 25 to 35 below zero range.

Snowfall amounts ranged from around 2 inches in Monroe to 10 inches over Bay and Huron counties. In addition, strong northeast winds gusting between 25 to 35 mph coming of Lake Huron and Saginaw Bay lead to some blowing and drifting of the snow north of I-69 as well.  Here are some of the higher snowfall reports received:||Harbor Beach... 10 inches.|Bay City (4N)... 10 inches.|Bad Axe...   9 inches.|Cass City... 8 inches. |Lapeer...    8 inches. |Columbiaville... 8 inches.|Marlette... 7 inches.|Leonard... 6 inches.|Manchester... 5 inches.|Detroit Metro... 4 inches.

A strong cold front moving across the area generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 8th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Eben Junction measured six inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving across the area generated moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow and blowing snow over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 8th into the 9th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of eight inches of lake effect snow in Newberry over a 24-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air pouring across Lake Superior generated moderate lake effect snow over western Alger County from the 9th into the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Eben Junction through Chatham to Forest Lake measured 8 to 9 inches of lake effect snow over a 24-hour period.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deep upper low pressure system from Hudson Bay into the Great Lakes brought a surge of Arctic air across the Upper Great Lakes which generated moderate to heavy lake effect snow and bitter cold temperatures across much of Upper Michigan from the 24th into 26th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of an estimated seven inches of lake effect snow in less than six hours at Rumely.  Nine inches of snowfall was also reported ten miles south of Grand Marais in less than 24 hours. Whiteout conditions were reported for several hours on the evening of the 24th due to considerable blowing and drifting of snow along Highway M-94.  Highway M-28 was also closed from Munising to Kawbawgam Road in Marquette County due to whiteout conditions. Wind chill values dropped into the 25 to 30 below zero range by the morning of the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were observed by webcams along Highway M-28 during the period. Northwest winds were likely gusting to 35 mph at times and the blizzard conditions kept Highway M-28 closed from the evening of the 7th through much of the 8th. Schools were dismissed early on the 7th and remained closed through the 8th due to the effects of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported by the observer in Grand Marais and observed at times on webcams along Highway M-28 during the period. Northwest winds were frequently gusting to 35 mph, especially near the shore of Lake Superior and the blizzard conditions kept Highway M-28 closed from the evening of the 7th through much of the 8th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of an estimated six to seven inches of snow in 11 hours near Menominee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strengthening low pressure moved into the southern Great Lakes, crossing southern lower Michigan during the daylight hours of the 28th. This resulted in a significant winter storm for most of northern lower Michigan. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were common on the 28th. Snowfall totals were mostly in the 7 to 13 inch range, and the highest amounts of around 16 inches fell near Cadillac and Lake City. Winds increased toward the tail end of the storm, resulting in increasing blowing and drifting snow. Very cold air was in place before the storm arrived, and returned as the storm exited. Wind chills of 15 to 30 below zero were common in northern lower Michigan. Wind chills were much colder in eastern upper Michigan, including -51 at Kinross, and -42 at Sault Ste Marie and Mackinac Island.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain accumulated to near a quarter of an inch during the morning of February 12th as low pressure lifted north toward the Lower Great Lakes region. This created difficult travel, along with scattered power outages due to falling trees and tree limbs.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain, at times mixed with sleet, accumulated up to 0.30 inches in spots on February 12th. Numerous slide-offs and minor accidents occurred across the county. Many schools and some businesses were closed on February 12th due to the icy conditions. Fallen tree branches were reported across the region, with many onto power lines creating scattered power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Weak low pressure would slowly organize as it moved east from Iowa. Initial light snow gave way to heavy snow as the system made its closest approach on the night of the 14th. The heaviest snowfall fell in eastern upper Michigan, mainly near and east of I-75. Hulbert picked up 11 inches of snow, while St Ignace, Hessel, Kinross, and Drummond Island were all in the 8 to 10 inch range.

Weak low pressure would slowly organize as it moved east from Iowa. Initial light snow gave way to heavy snow as the system made its closest approach on the night of the 14th. An upper level disturbance spread snow across the northern Great Lakes on the afternoon and night of the 5th. This snow was mostly light, however some bands of heavier snow focused on Mackinac County in eastern upper Michigan. Allenville and St Ignace picked up 6 to 7 inches of snow in a short time period, as accumulation rates reached 1 to 2 inches per hour.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated three to five inches of snow fell in approximately seven hours during the afternoon of the 7th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported by the observer in Grand Marais and observed on webcams along Highway M-28 during the period.  Northwest winds were frequently gusting to 35 mph at the Munising ASOS and the blizzard conditions kept Highway M-28 closed from the evening of the 7th through much of the 8th. Schools were dismissed early on the 7th and remained closed through the 8th due to the effects of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to five inches of wet snow was reported in 12 hours across the county, greatest far south near the city of Menominee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure would advance out of the central plains, crossing the Thumb area of lower Michigan on the night of the 12th. Snow expanded north into the area early on the 12th. Heavier snow fell in the morning into mid afternoon, followed by a brief lull, before heavier snow returned again that evening. Snowfall was enhanced into northeast lower Michigan during this part of the event, thanks to east winds off of Lake Huron. And, after the system departed, moderate lake effect snow fell in some of the snowbelts of northern Michigan well into the 13th. The highest snowfall amounts included 16 inches in Rogers City, and around a foot in Petoskey and Alpena. Substantial blowing and drifting snow resulted from winds gusting up to 40 mph after the system departed.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers in Manistique and Cooks measured three inches of wet snow in seven hours.  Sleet mixed in with the snow at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter near Ironwood measured 5.4 inches of wet snow in less than 18 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Herman measured three inches of snow in approximately ten hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Bergland measured 3.5 inches of snow in approximately ten hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter southeast of Big Bay measured 3.5 inches of snow in less than 11 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from near Redridge to Calumet measured six to seven inches of snow in less than 18 hours.  Large drifts were observed in Calumet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers seven miles southwest of Wetmore and near Grand Marais measured five to six inches of snow in 21 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow accumulated over the northwest wind snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 15th into the 16th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of 7.7 inches of lake effect snow in 18 hours at Ironwood.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system approaching from the Central Plains brought moderate snow to portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 9th into the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Three to four inches of wet snow was reported in the Escanaba-Gladstone area and in Stonington in just over a 12-hour period.

Another blast of arctic air impacted northern Michigan, behind a departing area of low pressure. Lake effect snow, gusty winds, blowing and drifting snow, and very low wind chills, combined to produce an abundance of winter weather hazards in northern Michigan. Wind chills bottomed out at 25 to 35 below zero in most of northern Michigan. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 7 inches were reported from Good Hart, Brethren, Boyne City, and Indian River.

The first severe weather and tornado event for 2019 in Southeast Michigan occurred on Thursday, March 14.  A large, powerful low pressure system moved up across the central Plains, with weather ranging from blizzards to tornadoes.  There were two rounds of weather that occurred across Southeast Michigan, the first round of severe weather raced northeast across the area as storms traveled at 100 mph!  The second round of severe weather, which is what brought the tornadoes to the area, was a line of thunderstorms that moved northeast just ahead of a cold front.  As this line moved across the area, there were multiple areas of circulation embedded with the line which resulted in four tornado touchdowns across Shiawassee and Genesee counties.  Three out of the four tornadoes were weak and rated an EF-0.  The tornado that hit near Vernon, MI, was rated an EF-2.  Some debris (insulation/lighter metal) from the M-71 area in Vernon was carried 7 miles by the tornado. The Shiawassee Emergency Manager reported 135 structures, 94 homes, 4 businesses, 16 barns and 22 RVs were damaged or destroyed in the wake of the storms.

Strengthening low pressure moved into the southern Great Lakes, crossing southern lower Michigan during the daylight hours of the 28th. This resulted in a significant winter storm for most of northern lower Michigan. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were common on the 28th. Snowfall totals were mostly in the 7 to 13 inch range, and the highest amounts of around 16 inches fell near Cadillac and Lake City. Winds increased toward the tail end of the storm, resulting in increasing blowing and drifting snow. Very cold air was in place before the storm arrived, and returned as the storm exited. Wind chills of 15 to 30 below zero were common in northern lower Michigan. Wind chills were much colder in eastern upper Michigan, including -51 at Kinross, and -42 at Sault Ste Marie and Mackinac Island.

A high-impact winter storm blasted northern Michigan with ice, snow, and wind. Intense low pressure would move almost due north up the long axis of Lake Michigan on the 24th. The initial push of precipitation into northern Michigan fell as freezing rain, with a number of places seeing around an eighth of an inch of ice accumulation on the day and night of the 23rd. Cold air blasted back into the region during the day and night of the 24th, on high westerly winds. That changed precipitation to snow, which diminished early on the 25th. The highest snowfall amounts were 11 inches near Gaylord, and 7 inches near Sault Ste Marie as well as Cadillac. Meanwhile, wind gusts of 40 to 60 mph were common during the day and night of the 24th. Mackinac Island had a measured gust to 63 mph, and Traverse City gusted to 60 mph. A few trees were downed by the wind here and there. The combination of snow and wind resulted in outright blizzard conditions across a good portion of northern Michigan - a rarity. Many roads (especially north-south roads) were rendered impassable by blowing and drifting snow, and drifts as high as 6 feet were not unheard of. Travel became nearly impossible by late afternoon of the 24th, and remained that way until the snow was gradually cleaned up on the 25th or even later.

A few trees were downed by the wind here and there. The combination of snow and wind resulted in outright blizzard conditions across a good portion of northern Michigan - a rarity. Many roads (especially north-south roads) were rendered impassable by blowing and drifting snow, and drifts as high as 6 feet were not unheard of. Travel became nearly impossible by late afternoon of the 24th, and remained that way until the snow was gradually cleaned up on the 25th or even later.

The first severe weather and tornado event for 2019 in Southeast Michigan occurred on Thursday, March 14.  A large, powerful low pressure system moved up across the central Plains, with weather ranging from blizzards to tornadoes.  There were two rounds of weather that occurred across Southeast Michigan, the first round of severe weather raced northeast across the area as storms traveled at 100 mph!  The second round of severe weather, which is what brought the tornadoes to the area, was a line of thunderstorms that moved northeast just ahead of a cold front.  As this line moved across the area, there were multiple areas of circulation embedded with the line which resulted in four tornado touchdowns across Shiawassee and Genesee counties.  Three out of the four tornadoes were weak and rated an EF-0.  The tornado that hit near Vernon, MI, was rated an EF-2.  Some debris (insulation/lighter metal) from the M-71 area in Vernon was carried 7 miles by the tornado. The Shiawassee Emergency Manager reported 135 structures, 94 homes, 4 businesses, 16 barns and 22 RVs were damaged or destroyed in the wake of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees blown down, along with a porch roof blown off .

Strengthening low pressure moved into the southern Great Lakes, crossing southern lower Michigan during the daylight hours of the 28th. This resulted in a significant winter storm for most of northern lower Michigan. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour were common on the 28th. Snowfall totals were mostly in the 7 to 13 inch range, and the highest amounts of around 16 inches fell near Cadillac and Lake City. Winds increased toward the tail end of the storm, resulting in increasing blowing and drifting snow. Very cold air was in place before the storm arrived, and returned as the storm exited. Wind chills of 15 to 30 below zero were common in northern lower Michigan. Wind chills were much colder in eastern upper Michigan, including -51 at Kinross, and -42 at Sault Ste Marie and Mackinac Island.

Another blast of arctic air impacted northern Michigan, behind a departing area of low pressure. Lake effect snow, gusty winds, blowing and drifting snow, and very low wind chills, combined to produce an abundance of winter weather hazards in northern Michigan. Wind chills bottomed out at 25 to 35 below zero in most of northern Michigan. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 7 inches were reported from Good Hart, Brethren, Boyne City, and Indian River.

Rapidly intensifying low pressure would pass to our west and north, eventually reaching James Bay. Warmer air surged into the region aloft ahead of the system, resulting in another wintry mix in the region. Parts of northern lower Michigan saw freezing rain of around a quarter of an inch during the day on the 7th, including Gaylord, Grayling, Higgins Lake, Charlevoix, and Alpena. Cold air rushed back in behind the departing system, and locally heavy lake effect snow developed, especially from Leelanau County to Otsego County. A quick 6 to 8 inches of snow fell on parts of the Gaylord area during the early morning hours of the 8th.

Low pressure would advance out of the central plains, crossing the Thumb area of lower Michigan on the night of the 12th. Snow expanded north into the area early on the 12th. Heavier snow fell in the morning into mid afternoon, followed by a brief lull, before heavier snow returned again that evening. Snowfall was enhanced into northeast lower Michigan during this part of the event, thanks to east winds off of Lake Huron. And, after the system departed, moderate lake effect snow fell in some of the snowbelts of northern Michigan well into the 13th. The highest snowfall amounts included 16 inches in Rogers City, and around a foot in Petoskey and Alpena. Substantial blowing and drifting snow resulted from winds gusting up to 40 mph after the system departed.

Meanwhile, wind gusts of 40 to 60 mph were common during the day and night of the 24th. Mackinac Island had a measured gust to 63 mph, and Traverse City gusted to 60 mph. A few trees were downed by the wind here and there. The combination of snow and wind resulted in outright blizzard conditions across a good portion of northern Michigan - a rarity. Many roads (especially north-south roads) were rendered impassable by blowing and drifting snow, and drifts as high as 6 feet were not unheard of. Travel became nearly impossible by late afternoon of the 24th, and remained that way until the snow was gradually cleaned up on the 25th or even later.

A high-impact winter storm blasted northern Michigan with ice, snow, and wind. Intense low pressure would move almost due north up the long axis of Lake Michigan on the 24th. The initial push of precipitation into northern Michigan fell as freezing rain, with a number of places seeing around an eighth of an inch of ice accumulation on the day and night of the 23rd. Cold air blasted back into the region during the day and night of the 24th, on high westerly winds. That changed precipitation to snow, which diminished early on the 25th. The highest snowfall amounts were 11 inches near Gaylord, and 7 inches near Sault Ste Marie as well as Cadillac. Meanwhile, wind gusts of 40 to 60 mph were common during the day and night of the 24th. Mackinac Island had a measured gust to 63 mph, and Traverse City gusted to 60 mph. A few trees were downed by the wind here and there. The combination of snow and wind resulted in outright blizzard conditions across a good portion of northern Michigan - a rarity. Many roads (especially north-south roads) were rendered impassable by blowing and drifting snow, and drifts as high as 6 feet were not unheard of. Travel became nearly impossible by late afternoon of the 24th, and remained that way until the snow was gradually cleaned up on the 25th or even later.

Another blast of arctic air impacted northern Michigan, behind a departing area of low pressure. Lake effect snow, gusty winds, blowing and drifting snow, and very low wind chills, combined to produce an abundance of winter weather hazards in northern Michigan. Wind chills bottomed out at 25 to 35 below zero in most of northern Michigan. Snowfall amounts of 5 to 7 inches were reported from Good Hart, Brethren, Boyne City, and Indian River.

Low pressure would advance out of the central plains, crossing the Thumb area of lower Michigan on the night of the 12th. Snow expanded north into the area early on the 12th. Heavier snow fell in the morning into mid afternoon, followed by a brief lull, before heavier snow returned again that evening. Snowfall was enhanced into northeast lower Michigan during this part of the event, thanks to east winds off of Lake Huron. And, after the system departed, moderate lake effect snow fell in some of the snowbelts of northern Michigan well into the 13th. The highest snowfall amounts included 16 inches in Rogers City, and around a foot in Petoskey and Alpena. Substantial blowing and drifting snow resulted from winds gusting up to 40 mph after the system departed.

A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers across Ontonagon County measured between four and six inches of wet snow over an approximate 12-hour period.  Sleet likely mixed in with the snow at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters reported between four to six inches of heavy wet snow during the late afternoon and evening hours across northern Houghton County.  Snowfall rates of an inch per hour or greater combined with east winds gusting to 45 mph caused near whiteout conditions and power outages from late afternoon into the early morning of the 12th.  Schools through the county were closed on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated four to six inches of wet snow over approximately 9 hours. Sleet likely mixed in with the snow at times.  East winds gusting to 40 mph also caused near whiteout conditions at times in snow and blowing snow and power outages during the evening of the 11th.  Many area schools were closed on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters measured between four and seven inches of wet snow in approximately 10 hours.  Area schools were closed on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter at Marenisco measured nearly six inches of wet snow in less than ten hours.  Sleet also mixed in with the snow at times.  A few schools had delayed start times on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A mix of wet snow and sleet accumulated from three to six inches over much of Iron County on the 11th.  West Iron County Schools were closed on the 12th to impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated four to six inches of wet snow in less than ten hours across the county.  Sleet mixed in with the snow at times.  Area schools were closed on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotter reports throughout the county measured anywhere from three to six inches of wet snow over an approximate 10-hour time period.  Marquette Board of Light and Power reported scattered power outages from the wet snow, and area schools were closed throughout the county on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Freezing rain accumulated between one to two tenths of an inch of ice in Newberry from late evening on the 11th through the early morning of the 12th.  The freezing rain and east winds gusting over 30 mph at times caused scattered power outages over the county. The freezing rain also mixed with snow and sleet at times on the morning of the 12th. Tahquamenon Area Schools were delayed two hours on the 12th due to the impacts from the mixed precipitation and gusty winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front draped across the region provided a focus for thunderstorm development. Although MUCAPE was 500 J/KG or less across the region, 0 to 3 km helicity in excess of 500 m2/s2 and effective shear of 60 to 80 knots allowed for some organization to storms with hail and isolated wind damage being the main impacts.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season system brought heavy snow to portions of west central lower Michigan.  Up to nine inches of snow was reported near Big Rapids and Sylvester in Mecosta county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Nine inches of snow was reported by CoCoRaHs observers near Big Rapids and Sylvester.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season system brought heavy snow to portions of west central lower Michigan.  Up to nine inches of snow was reported near Big Rapids and Sylvester in Mecosta county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported six inches of snow near White Cloud.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A late season brought high winds with several locations reporting peak wind gusts of 45 to near 60 mph.  A peak wind gust to 59 mph was reported at the Muskegon airport. There were also several reports of one to three inches of snow north of I-96.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A peak wind gust of 59 mph was measured at the Muskegon airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first severe weather and tornado event for 2019 in Southeast Michigan occurred on Thursday, March 14.  A large, powerful low pressure system moved up across the central Plains, with weather ranging from blizzards to tornadoes.  There were two rounds of weather that occurred across Southeast Michigan, the first round of severe weather raced northeast across the area as storms traveled at 100 mph!  The second round of severe weather, which is what brought the tornadoes to the area, was a line of thunderstorms that moved northeast just ahead of a cold front.  As this line moved across the area, there were multiple areas of circulation embedded with the line which resulted in four tornado touchdowns across Shiawassee and Genesee counties.  Three out of the four tornadoes were weak and rated an EF-0.  The tornado that hit near Vernon, MI, was rated an EF-2.  Some debris (insulation/lighter metal) from the M-71 area in Vernon was carried 7 miles by the tornado. The Shiawassee Emergency Manager reported 135 structures, 94 homes, 4 businesses, 16 barns and 22 RVs were damaged or destroyed in the wake of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down close to the intersection of Bennington Greens Drive and Innsbrook Drive, snapping pine trees. The tornado continued northeast, crossing M-52 near West Grand River Road. Hardwood trees were observed snapped with large limbs down. The tornado then hit a Farm along South Morrice Road, just south of W Garrison Road. Trees were uprooted and a well built farm outbuilding lost its roof. The tornado snapped additional trees near Vandecarr and Bennington Roads before lifting near the Maple River.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first severe weather and tornado event for 2019 in Southeast Michigan occurred on Thursday, March 14.  A large, powerful low pressure system moved up across the central Plains, with weather ranging from blizzards to tornadoes.  There were two rounds of weather that occurred across Southeast Michigan, the first round of severe weather raced northeast across the area as storms traveled at 100 mph!  The second round of severe weather, which is what brought the tornadoes to the area, was a line of thunderstorms that moved northeast just ahead of a cold front.  As this line moved across the area, there were multiple areas of circulation embedded with the line which resulted in four tornado touchdowns across Shiawassee and Genesee counties.  Three out of the four tornadoes were weak and rated an EF-0.  The tornado that hit near Vernon, MI, was rated an EF-2.  Some debris (insulation/lighter metal) from the M-71 area in Vernon was carried 7 miles by the tornado. The Shiawassee Emergency Manager reported 135 structures, 94 homes, 4 businesses, 16 barns and 22 RVs were damaged or destroyed in the wake of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tornado touched down near the intersection of Stanley and Bray Roads and quickly tracked off to the northeast. The storm lifted near the M-57 and Irish Road intersection. The tornado was strongest when it hit the Camelot Villas off of Genesee Road. A mobile home was flipped onto its side, with another mobile home partially blown off the foundation. Roof and siding damage was prevalent within the mobile park. Clusters of trees were snapped and tree tops sheared along the tornado path, with a couple other small trailers flipped.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down on Nichols Rd just south of Corunna Rd before traveling east/northeast to Calkins Rd just east of Morrish Rd. Damage included downed and snapped trees, large limbs, and a collapsed pole barn.  The tornado lifted near Jennings Rd just north of Pasadena Ave.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: The first severe weather and tornado event for 2019 in Southeast Michigan occurred on Thursday, March 14.  A large, powerful low pressure system moved up across the central Plains, with weather ranging from blizzards to tornadoes.  There were two rounds of weather that occurred across Southeast Michigan, the first round of severe weather raced northeast across the area as storms traveled at 100 mph!  The second round of severe weather, which is what brought the tornadoes to the area, was a line of thunderstorms that moved northeast just ahead of a cold front.  As this line moved across the area, there were multiple areas of circulation embedded with the line which resulted in four tornado touchdowns across Shiawassee and Genesee counties.  Three out of the four tornadoes were weak and rated an EF-0.  The tornado that hit near Vernon, MI, was rated an EF-2.  Some debris (insulation/lighter metal) from the M-71 area in Vernon was carried 7 miles by the tornado. The Shiawassee Emergency Manager reported 135 structures, 94 homes, 4 businesses, 16 barns and 22 RVs were damaged or destroyed in the wake of the storms.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The tornado touched down around the intersection of Britton Rd and I-69 and produced EF-0 damage up to Bancroft Rd and Newburg Rd with large tree limbs downed and trees snapped. Shoreline Lake Condos had over 10 trailers and mobile homes damaged from falling trees. The tornado continued northeast from Bancroft Rd/Newburg Rd to M-71 just ESE of Vernon producing EF-2 damage. One roof was completely taken off, a second story wall collapsed, and numerous homes with wall damage.  The tornado weakened back down to EF-1 as two more home damaged near Bennington Rd Reed Rd.  The tornado finally lifted near Riniel Rd just south of Lytle Rd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Between four and eight inches of wet snow fell over much of Menominee County during the event.  Sleet mixed in with the snow at times. East winds gusting over 30 mph at times also caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow as well.  Many schools throughout the county were closed on the 12th due to impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers across the county measured between four and seven inches of snow over a 14-hour period.  Sleet mixed in with the snow at times.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A Plains storm system tracking into the Great Lakes brought moderate to heavy snow and sleet to the west half of Upper Michigan on the 11th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of two to three inches of wet heavy snow in less than five hours in Escanaba.  Scattered power outages were reported due to the heavy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure would strengthen as it moved northeast across the eastern Great Lakes on the night of the 14th. Other than a touch of rain at onset, precipitation was almost exclusively snow in northern lower Michigan. Snowfall totals of six to nine inches were common, along and southeast of a line from Cadillac to Alpena. However, the only concentrated area that reported over eight inches of snow was in Roscommon County. Eight to nine inches of snow fell on Roscommon, Houghton and Higgins Lake, St Helen, and the Twin Lakes area.

Snow pack with 2 inches of liquid water equivalent melted, coupled with rainfall slightly above half of an inch, caused the Tittabawassee River at Midland  to reach moderate flood level. The river peaked at 25.41 feet during the morning of March 16th.  Several roads were closed due to flooding, including parts of US-10.
Anomalously wet late season snow pack along with a period of moderate rainfall caused minor flooding on the Sturgeon River from the 8th until early on the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Abundant and wet snow pack along with moderate rainfall at times contributed to minor flooding along the Sturgeon River from the 8th into early on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On the 20th, the Big Cedar River near Powers was inundating yards up near a few porches.  Other minor roads in Menominee County were reportedly under some water during this time.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Norrie Park Road in Ironwood between Lime Street and Riverside Road was closed on the 22nd due to the failure of a small, old dam on the Montreal River.  Water was also reported over Black River Road near McDonald Dam on April 22.  On April 24th, numerous road closures were reported in the City of Wakefield as the Little Black River and Sunday Lake rose outside their banks. The city enlisted students to fill and place sandbags around the city.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred into Dickinson County along the Michigamme River from the 23rd through the end of the month.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor flooding along the Sturgeon River from the 18th through the end of the month.  ||The Houghton County emergency manager reported that several houses and barns near the Sturgeon River at Chassell had rising water around them but no structures were inundated.  Sturgeon River Road was reported to be under 6-8 inches of water and Rajala Road was under 8-10 inches of water.  Multiple sections of Halonen Road near Pelkie and adjacent fields were reported to be under water the morning of 04/23 as the Sturgeon River crested.  Rain and snow melt runoff along with some clogged culverts led to Highway M-26 being closed south of Hubbell on the night of the 22nd due to water over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Abundant wet snow pack combined with moderate to heavy rain at times caused minor flooding along the Michigamme River near Republic and Witch Lake and along the Middle Branch of the Escanaba near Humboldt from 23rd through the end of the month.  Some minor flooding was also reported along the Chocolay River near Harvey from the 18th through the 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Gages Creek overflowed its banks onto private property east of Peavy Pond on April 19th.  Minor flooding was also reported on the Paint and Michigamme Rivers from the 23rd into the 26th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Abundant and anomalously wet snow pack along with periods of moderate to heavy rain contributed to widespread minor river flooding across much of west and central Upper Michigan from the 18th through the end of the month.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Willow Creek in Escanaba spilled over onto Willow Creek Road on the 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe storm brought down a tree that fell on Sugar Grove road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a moist and unstable air mass generated a few severe thunderstorms over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorm wind damage pictures received via the internet indicated an anchored trampoline was tossed around, and half of a large tree was downed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a moist and unstable air mass generated a few severe thunderstorms over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Keweenaw County emergency manager reported numerous trees down on the road to Lac La Belle causing the road to become impassable.   The time of the report was estimated from the radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A cold front moving through a moist and unstable air mass generated a few severe thunderstorms over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A video was relayed via social media of an eight-inch diameter tree downed in Houghton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance from the Central Plains moved across the Upper Great Lakes and produced moderate snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Moderate snow accumulation ranging from four to six inches occurred over a 12-hour period from Michigamme east to Negaunee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level disturbance from the Central Plains moved across the Upper Great Lakes and produced moderate snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four to five inches wet snow fell in less than eight hours over higher terrain from Painesdale north to Calumet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms dropped one inch diameter hail over portions of Delta County on the evening of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch diameter hail fell in downtown Gladstone.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe thunderstorms dropped one inch diameter hail over portions of Delta County on the evening of the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One inch diameter hail fell two miles northwest of Isabella.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong west to northwest winds gusting in excess of 40 mph uprooted a tree unto an RV trailer in Van Riper State Park campground on the afternoon of the 25th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Strong west to northwest winds gusting in excess of 40 mph uprooted a tree unto an RV trailer in Van Riper State Park campground on the afternoon of the 25th.  The tree was healthy so the observer suspected that the saturated ground contributed to it being uprooted.  The RV trailer was crushed by the tree, but no injuries were reported.  Many other branches came down at the campground.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rains of one to three inches over the weekend of 5/18-5/19 caused minor flooding of the Escanaba River at Humboldt and the Sturgeon River at Alston on the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding was reported at the Sturgeon River near Alston during the afternoon the early evening of the 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system quickly intensified over the weekend of February 23-24th, as it crossed the Great Lakes region.  This system brought blizzard warnings to western portions of the Great Lakes to high winds across the rest of the region.  A well-mixed boundary layer led to high winds over the region, with gusts around 60 mph range. Widespread downed tree limbs with sporadic structural damage reported. One such report was roof damage at Adrian College. Downed power lines led to close to 200,000 customers without power across southeast Michigan, with some of outages lasting into Monday. Here are some of the higher wind gusts reported:|Saginaw... 61 mph|Detroit...   61 mph|Pontiac...   56 mph|Flint...       55 mph|Ann Arbor...  55 mph|Adrian...       55 mph|Lapeer...       53 mph.

A low pressure system quickly intensified over the weekend of February 23-24th, as it crossed the Great Lakes region.  This system brought blizzard warnings to western portions of the Great Lakes to high winds across the rest of the region.  A well-mixed boundary layer led to high winds over the region, with gusts around 60 mph range. Widespread downed tree limbs with sporadic structural damage reported. One such report was roof damage at Adrian College. Downed power lines led to close to 200,000 customers without power across southeast Michigan, with some of outages lasting into Monday. Here are some of the higher wind gusts reported:|Saginaw... 61 mph|Detroit...   61 mph|Pontiac...   56 mph|Flint...       55 mph|Ann Arbor...  55 mph|Adrian...       55 mph|Lapeer...       53 mph.

A powerful bomb cyclone developing over the Central Plains and moving into the Great Lakes region produced heavy snow and blizzard conditions across much of the Upper Michigan from the 24th into early on the 25th. The accumulated heavy snow from this event and storms earlier in the month caused roof collapses of numerous businesses and a few farm buildings as well across portions of Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer just north of Iron Mountain measured six inches of wet snow in less than four hours.  Many churches and businesses were closed on the 24th due to impacts from the storm. Schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th due to lingering impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering Arctic air mass across the region continued to support bitter cold wind chill temperatures of 25 to 40 below zero on the morning of February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values ranged from 30 to 35 below zero on the morning of the 1st.  Schools were closed throughout the county due to the bitter cold wind chills.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering Arctic air mass across the region continued to support bitter cold wind chill temperatures of 25 to 40 below zero on the morning of February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values ranged from 30 to 35 below zero on the morning of the 1st. Schools were closed throughout the county on the 1st due to the bitter cold wind chills.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering Arctic air mass across the region continued to support bitter cold wind chill temperatures of 25 to 40 below zero on the morning of February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values across Dickinson County ranged from 25 to 30 below zero on the morning of the 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A lingering Arctic air mass across the region continued to support bitter cold wind chill temperatures of 25 to 40 below zero on the morning of February 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind chill values ranged from 30 to 35 below zero on the morning of the 1st. Wakefield-Marenisco classes were delayed two hours due to the bitter cold wind chills and Watersmeet Schools were closed.

A powerful bomb cyclone developing over the Central Plains and moving into the Great Lakes region produced heavy snow and blizzard conditions across much of the Upper Michigan from the 24th into early on the 25th. The accumulated heavy snow from this event and storms earlier in the month caused roof collapses of numerous businesses and a few farm buildings as well across portions of Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated three to four inches of wet snow fell in five hours across much of the county.  This wet snow combined with the weight of snow from previous storms earlier in the month caused damage to three farm buildings in Harris Township.  One free stall barn collapsed and killed 27 cows.  Damage estimates from the loss of the buildings and livestock approached $150,000.  Many churches and businesses were closed on the 24th due to impacts from the storm. Many schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th due to lingering impacts from the storm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated three to five inches of snow fell in the Escanaba-Gladstone area in less than six hours.  Many churches and businesses were closed on the 24th due to impacts from the storm. Schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th due to lingering impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through the Upper Great Lakes dropped significant ice accumulation across much of Upper Michigan on the 4th.  As a result, schools were closed throughout Upper Michigan on the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: One quarter to one half inch of ice accumulation occurred across Dickinson County on the morning of the 4th. The ice caused tree damage and power outages across the county which impacted hundreds of Wisconsin Electric customers from Iron Mountain to Ralph.  Numerous accidents were also reported by law enforcement.  Schools throughout the county were closed on the 4th due to the impacts from the ice accumulation.

A deepening low pressure system tracking just southeast of Upper Michigan brought moderate to heavy lake enhanced snow to mainly the northwest wind Lake Superior snow belts of Upper Michigan from the 14th into the 15th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report near Newberry of eight inches of lake enhanced snow in 12 hours. Tahquamenon Area Schools were closed on the 15th due to the heavy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to locally heavy lake effect snow occurred over portions of Marquette County from the 17th into the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Marquette National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured eight inches of lake effect snow in 24 hours. Nearly nine inches of snowfall was reported five miles northwest of Ishpeming. There was a report of locally heavy lake effect snow seven miles southwest of Big Bay where an estimated 13 inches of snowfall fell over approximately 24 hours.

The accumulated heavy snow from this event and storms earlier in the month caused roof collapses of numerous businesses and a few farm buildings as well across portions of Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported throughout the county during the afternoon of the 24th and continuing into the morning of the 25th.  Northwest winds, gusting to an estimated 45 mph at times, caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow as many roads were drifted shut and closed, including Highway M-28.  Schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th.
