EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought a wintry mix to southeast Michigan on February 12th.  Snow started to work in across the area from the Ohio border around midnight and continued to move north into the morning hours. Warmer air aloft also moved in from south to north and led to the development of a mix of precipitation across the region. Easterly winds gusting to around 25 mph during the morning fed plenty of cold Canadian air to the surface, allowing for freezing rain to dominate south of Detroit where tens of thousands of residents lost power. Ice accumulation up to 3 tenths of an inch was observed over Monroe and Lenawee counties.  Sleet was more prevalent to the north. Eventually temperatures rose above freezing by the late morning, leading to a changeover to liquid rain. Precipitation tapered off across the region by early afternoon as the system's dry slot moved in. Snowfall amounts north of M-59 ranged from 2 to 6 inches, with the highest totals occurring north of M-46.

Northwest winds gusting to 50 to 60 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and closed many roads, including Highway M-28 east of Harvey.  Some higher terrain locations across the county reported nearly two feet of storm total snowfall.  The weight of heavy snow from this storm and previous storms during the month of February caused numerous roof collapses of businesses throughout the county.  The heavy snow also caused the roof of the Negaunee Bus Depot to collapse which alone caused damage in the hundreds of thousands of dollars.  Schools throughout the county, including Northern Michigan University, were closed on the 25th due to lingering effects from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A powerful bomb cyclone developing over the Central Plains and moving into the Great Lakes region produced heavy snow and blizzard conditions across much of the Upper Michigan from the 24th into early on the 25th. The accumulated heavy snow from this event and storms earlier in the month caused roof collapses of numerous businesses and a few farm buildings as well across portions of Upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Blizzard conditions were reported throughout the county during the afternoon and evening of the 24th. Northwest winds gusting to 50 to 60 mph caused considerable blowing and drifting of snow and closed many secondary roads. Some locations across the county reported nearly two feet of storm total snowfall.  Schools throughout the county were closed on the 25th due to lingering effects from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong low pressure system brought a wintry mix to southeast Michigan on February 12th.  Snow started to work in across the area from the Ohio border around midnight and continued to move north into the morning hours. Warmer air aloft also moved in from south to north and led to the development of a mix of precipitation across the region. Easterly winds gusting to around 25 mph during the morning fed plenty of cold Canadian air to the surface, allowing for freezing rain to dominate south of Detroit where tens of thousands of residents lost power. Ice accumulation up to 3 tenths of an inch was observed over Monroe and Lenawee counties.  Sleet was more prevalent to the north. Eventually temperatures rose above freezing by the late morning, leading to a changeover to liquid rain. Precipitation tapered off across the region by early afternoon as the system's dry slot moved in. Snowfall amounts north of M-59 ranged from 2 to 6 inches, with the highest totals occurring north of M-46.

Northwest winds gusting to 60 mph at times caused extreme blowing and drifting of snow and closed all roads across the northern part of the county. All schools throughout the county, including Michigan Technological University, were closed on the 25th due to lingering impacts from the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper disturbance moving from the Central Plains into the Upper Great Lakes brought heavy snow to much of south central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 5th into the early morning of the 6th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of seven inches of snow at Daggett and eight inches of snow at Spalding in less than 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated eight to ten inched of snow in Baraga in less than seven hours. Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and were delayed two hours on the 8th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer in Norway measured six inches of snow in approximately nine hours. Bay College in Iron Mountain was dismissed early on the 7th due to the storm and many schools delayed classes two hours on the 8th due to the effects of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Social media reports observed ten inches of snow in seven hours at Bergland and Mass City.  Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and remained closed on the 8th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a media report of eight inches of snow in 12 hours at Copper Harbor.  Four inches of snow fell in less than three hours during the afternoon of the 7th.  Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and remained closed into the 8th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th. EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of six inches of snow in 12 hours at Ironwood.  There was a five hour period of one-inch per hour snowfall rates from late morning to mid afternoon on the 7th.  Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and remained closed into the 8th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system developed across the western Great Lakes on Sunday, February 24th. Widespread 30 to 40 mph prevailing west winds occurred with gusts of 45 to 68 mph. These high winds were of long duration (approximately 13-16 hours) and this was considered unprecedented based on local climatology. Numerous reports of downed large trees, large tree limbs, and utility poles were received along with many power outages across the entire area. The highest wind gust of the event was at KAOH with a 68 mph gust.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Long duration sustained winds of 35 to 45 mph with gusts of 50 to 55 mph occurred across the county, resulting in trees, tree limbs and power poles suffering damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through the Upper Great Lakes dropped significant ice accumulation across much of Upper Michigan on the 4th.  As a result, schools were closed throughout Upper Michigan on the 4th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer at Amasa measured a quarter-inch to one half inch of accumulation of ice during the storm.  Iron County Dispatch reported icy roads and tree damage from the storm.  Schools were closed throughout the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotters throughout the county measured three to four inches of snow in approximately six hours during the afternoon of the 7th.  Many schools throughout the county were closed on the 8th due to the effects of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong winter storm tracking through northern Lower Michigan dropped moderate to heavy snow across much of Upper Michigan on the 7th.  Northwest flow lake effect snow and extreme blowing snow behind the system caused blizzard conditions into Alger, Luce and northern Schoolcraft counties from late on the 7th into the 8th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A widespread seven to eight inches of snow fell across the northern half of the county in eight hours during the afternoon of the 7th. The heavy snow and poor visibility led to a two-vehicle crash near the Lakeshore Drive intersection in Ishpeming during the afternoon of the 7th which resulted three injured people.  Many schools throughout the county dismissed classes early on the 7th and remained closed on the 8th due to the storm. Highway M-28 was closed east of Harvey due to blizzard conditions by the evening of the 7th.  Strong northwest winds gusting near 45 mph on the morning of the 8th toppled a 8-10 inch diameter tree across North Road in Negaunee.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A rapidly deepening storm system moving from the Plains into Lower Michigan dumped heavy lake enhanced snow across much of Upper Michigan from the 12th into the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Storm total snowfall across the county ranged from 16 inches in Marquette to nearly 26 inches in Negaunee, including the NWS Marquette office, with one to two inch per hour snowfall rates observed during the event.  Calendar day snowfall records were broken on both the 12th and 13th at the NWS Marquette office and a daily precipitation record of 1.30 inches was set on the 12th.  Area schools were closed on both the 12th and the 13th due to the heavy snow, and Northern Michigan University was closed on the 13th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northerly to easterly winds resulted in another round of substantial coastal flooding and beach erosion, this time on both Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, for the 21st into the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: In Northport on the 21st, a dock was damaged and a boat house was flooded. Water levels rose over the docks at Northport Marina. On the 22nd in Empire, a part of the break wall at Empire Beach was destroyed. In Glen Haven, restoration efforts from flooding earlier in the month were eliminated, and shoreline fences were destroyed at Glen Haven Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of regenerating thunderstorms produced excessive rainfall and some severe weather in northern lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: See earlier flash flood event in Manistee County. Flooding lingered in southern Manistee County for much of the following night, with numerous roads closed and barricaded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A broken line of thunderstorms crossed eastern upper and northern lower Michigan on the evening of the 10th. A few storms become severe, with damaging winds the most common type of severe weather.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A few trees were downed.

A small cluster of severe thunderstorms impacted north central and northeast lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees, tree limbs and power lines were downed. One road northeast of Sand Lake was blocked.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe thunderstorm produced a substantial downburst in the Houghton Lake area.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Many trees and power lines were downed. Some vehicles, homes, cottages, and other buildings were damaged by falling trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of regenerating thunderstorms produced excessive rainfall and some severe weather in northern lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms moved repeatedly over Manistee County in the morning and afternoon of the 20th. Excessive rainfall produced substantial flooding across central and southern Manistee County. By late on the 20th, rainfall totals reached 8.90 in Parkdale (near Manistee), and 5.95 in Wellston. Water entered numerous homes and stores in the greater Manistee area, and in Dublin, resulting in property damage. The campground at Orchard Beach State Park was at one point under four feet of water. Many roads were flooded and closed to travel for several hours. 12th Street in the city of Manistee was washed out. Places near the Manistee River were most susceptible to flooding.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A well-organized squall line would weaken as it crossed northern Lake Michigan and northwest lower Michigan. However, a few locations saw damaging wind gusts.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Scattered trees were downed from the Beulah area to near Cinder and Homestead Roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A large area of regenerating thunderstorms produced excessive rainfall and some severe weather in northern lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed. One large downed tree blocked M-22 north of Suttons Bay.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system moving from the Northern Plains across western Lake Superior produced strong east to southeast winds across the area which induced lakeshore flooding over the Bay of Green Bay and portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous reports, pictures and videos posted on social media of multiple properties, houses and buildings inundated with water along Highway M-35 from Menominee to Cedar River on the 21st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system moving from the Northern Plains across western Lake Superior produced strong east to southeast winds across the area which induced lakeshore flooding over the Bay of Green Bay and portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were numerous social media posts of pictures and video documenting the lakeshore flooding in Gladstone and Escanaba on the 21st.  Pictures and reports included flooding of parking lots and pier structures by the Gladstone Harbor and Yacht Club, and flooding of Ludington Park and basement flooding of homes along Lake Shore Drive in Escanaba. Piers and the Municipal Dock at the Escanaba Yacht Club were also flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system moving from the Northern Plains across western Lake Superior produced strong east to southeast winds across the area which induced lakeshore flooding over the Bay of Green Bay and portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: East winds gusting near 50 mph at times caused power outages across Keweenaw County.  UPPCO reported about 1400 customers without power in Copper Harbor, Lac La Belle and Bete Grise due to the strong winds.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An intense low pressure system moving from the Northern Plains across western Lake Superior produced strong east to southeast winds across the area which induced lakeshore flooding over the Bay of Green Bay and portions of the Keweenaw Peninsula on the 21st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Big Bay Lighthouse weather station measured a peak wind gust of 60 mph at a height of 120 feet.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Rapidly deepening low pressure over Ontario caused waves of 10 to 14 feet along the lakeshore areas of Berrien county. This combined with already high water levels to cause flooding in several locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media sharing photos and video of flooding working inland from Lake Michigan into coastal areas of New Buffalo, especially along North Whittaker St. Some road closures were noted.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: North winds gusting over 40 mph built waves to near 11 feet along the shoreline of Marquette on the 16th.  The wave action caused flooding along Lakeshore Boulevard, closing a section of the road from Fair Street to Hawley Avenue.  Presque Isle Park was also closed due to the high waves.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: North winds gusting over 40 mph built waves to near 11 feet along the shoreline of Marquette on the 16th.  The wave action caused flooding along Lakeshore Boulevard, closing a section of the road from Fair Street to Hawley Avenue.  Presque Isle Park was also closed due to the high waves.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported down on power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A thunderstorm produced a 58 mph wind gust at Detroit Metro Airport.

Strong and prolonged northwest winds around 35 mph generated large waves over Saginaw Bay and southern Lake Huron. These higher waves and elevated water levels caused significant lakeshore flooding.  Flooding to homes and roads were reported in Harbor Beach, Caseville, and Sebewaing. Erosion of the shoreline occurred at Port Crescent State Park. Finally, significant erosion and damage to seawalls reported in Lakeport.

Easterly winds around 20 MPH and high water levels over Lake Erie lead to lakeshore flooding along the Monroe and southern Wayne shorelines. The water level at Toledo peaked at 76.8 inches above chart datum, while Fermi and Gibraltar water levels peaked just under 72 inches above chart datum.

An isolated severe storm in Montcalm county brought down numerous trees and limbs and power lines across portions of Montcalm county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An isolated severe storm produced high winds that blew several six to eight inch diameter trees down onto a barn near Howard City.  Evergreen township was particularly hard hit with numerous trees down.  Over seven thousand people in Montcalm county lost power.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two to nearly five inches of rain fell across portions of west central lower Michigan and resulted in some flooding of area roads and low lying areas.  Several roads were closed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple cars were flooded on Mission street in Mt. Pleasant.  One unit in an apartment complex also had flooding in that area.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Reeds Lake boulevard was flooded in two low lying spots between Manhattan road and the outlet to the east and the bike path was also flooded.  Balyeat field in Sparta was inundated with water when Nash Creek flowed out of it's banks.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Newaygo county emergency manager reported several road closures.  Luce avenue between 24th and 32nd was closed, and Van Buren avenue was closed east of North Spruce all due to water over the roads.   112th street was also closed between Dickinson and Fitzgerald avenues due to water over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A 30-year-old man got caught in a rip current and drowned while swimming at a county park in Hume Township near Port Austin.

High water levels over Lake Huron and northeast to north winds of 30-40 MPH produced large waves resulting in lakeshore flooding across Bay, Tuscola, and Huron Counties. The water level at Essexville peaked at 71.3 inches above chart datum.  Shoreline erosion was reported at Port Hope.

High water levels over Lake Huron and northeast to north winds of 30-40 MPH produced large waves resulting in lakeshore flooding across Bay, Tuscola, and Huron Counties. The water level at Essexville peaked at 71.3 inches above chart datum.  Shoreline erosion was reported at Port Hope.
Two severe thunderstorms developed around Owosso and Swartz Creek, leading to tree damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: At least 20 trees were snapped from a wet micro-burst close to the Shiawassee river in Owosso. Many of trees appeared unhealthy.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Numerous roads became impassable from heavy rain throughout Canton, with cars flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: High water levels over Lake Huron and northeast to north winds of 30-40 MPH produced large waves resulting in lakeshore flooding across Bay, Tuscola, and Huron Counties. The water level at Essexville peaked at 71.3 inches above chart datum.  Shoreline erosion was reported at Port Hope.
Isolated severe storms produced sporadic wind damage in the form of a few downed trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A round of severe storms resulted in numerous reports of downed trees and power lines. Peak wind gusts were estimated at up to around 70 to 80 mph.  In addition 6 to 10 inches of rain fell across much of Mason and Lake counties.  There were several road washouts, a few culvert failures, and a couple of bridge washouts.  At least 48 homes were damaged by water in Lake county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees were blown down county wide and Croton was especially hard hit.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A line of thunderstorms crossed far northern lower Michigan, and adjoining portions of the Great Lakes, on the afternoon of the 30th.

Numerous strong to severe numerous thunderstorms developed in the late afternoon hours, mainly along and south of the M-59 corridor. The main hazard was wind damage, with downed trees and power-lines. However, there was a few occurrences of hail around 1 inch in diameter reported in Livingston and Washtenaw counties.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A slow-moving cold front interacting with a moist and unstable air mass produced heavy rainfall of three to six inches and flash flooding over portions of Menominee County on the morning of the 19th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The Menominee County Dispatch reported County Road G12 closed due to flash flooding from heavy rainfall.  Additional minor to moderate flooding was also reported on other back county roads.  The NWS Marquette radar estimated five to six inches of rainfall in the Stephenson area on the morning of the 19th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm struck the roof of the Superior Hotel in Grand Marais and caused a rooftop fire on the afternoon of the 30th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Lightning from a thunderstorm caused a rooftop fire at the Superior Hotel in Grand Marais on the afternoon of the 30th.  Time of the report was estimated via ENTLN and GLD lightning data.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Prolonged easterly winds of 10 to 20 mph lead to lakeshore flooding along the Western Lake Erie shoreline and Lake St. Clair shoreline. The water level at Toledo peaked at 81 inches above LWD around noon on July 7th, while Fermi and  Gibraltar both peaked close to 78 inches. Meanwhile, across Lake St. Clair, St. Clair shores peaked around 67 inches above LWD in the late evening hours of July 7th, while Windmill Point reached their peak during the late evening hours of July 6th just above 67 inches.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Renewed easterly winds of 30 to 35 mph on April 14th sent water levels over Western Lake Erie up once again, with peak water levels coming up a few inches short from the April 11th values. None-the-less, renewed lakeshore flooding was reported in many of the same areas.

Renewed easterly winds of 30 to 35 mph on April 14th sent water levels over Western Lake Erie up once again, with peak water levels coming up a few inches short from the April 11th values. None-the-less, renewed lakeshore flooding was reported in many of the same areas.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A narrow line of thunderstorms produced intense rainfall rates, with 3 to 6 inches of rain occurring over eastern Oakland and western Macomb Counties. M-59 was closed due to flooding northeast of Troy, along with Square Lake and John R roads.  In addition, cars were flooded and stuck on 19 mile and Mound roads. Numerous roads were also reported flooded throughout Sterling Heights and Clinton Township.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A brief, weak tornado touched down near New Lothrup.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak tornado touched down near Allan and New Lothrup roads and tracked off to the northeast, lifting close to North Byron Road between Easton and Johnston roads. Maple trees were observed uprooted along the path. A small garage and pole barn were destroyed. At least 1 home suffered structural damage, with 2 homes suffering mostly shingle damage. A propane tank was also moved by the wind. The maximum peak winds was 85 mph.

This resulted in thousands of downed trees, limbs and power lines.  Approximately one hundred and fifty thousand people lost power.  |Schools in the area were closed for days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A half to three quarters of an inch of freezing rain resulted in numerous downed trees, limbs, power lines and widespread power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain with thunderstorms produced 2 to 4 inches of rain in about a 4 hour window across the I-94 corridor. This amount of rain in a short period caused flash flooding across parts of Wayne County, with the Dearborn Heights area being hardest hit. About 5000 homes experienced basement flooding, with 1000 homes or so suffering major flood damage.  Several road closures occurred or were rendered impassable as  many cars were stalled out in the high water over the roadways.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The excessive rainfall also caused flooding across Ecorse Creek and Rouge River. Ecorse Creek in Dearborn Heights peaked at 9.77 feet during the early morning hours of May 1st. The Lower Rouge River at Dearborn peaked just above 10.5 feet around noon on May 1st.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Record high water levels over Lake Erie, coupled with easterly winds of 20 to 30 MPH lead to lakeshore flooding across eastern Monroe, and eastern Wayne County. The water level at Toledo peak at 86 inches at 1536 LST on May 8th, with Fermi and Gibraltar peaking at 78 inches and 76 inches respectively about an hour later. The Village of Estral Beach observed homeowners stranded in their homes due to the flood waters, with Firefighters assisting in evacuations. While Estral Beach residents were hit hardest by the flood waters from Lake Erie, several county beachfront communities also were inundated by water, particularly in Grand Beach in Frenchtown Township, North Shores in LaSalle, Avalon Beach in Monroe Township and Allen Cove in Luna Pier.

Thunderstorms produced heavy rain, with 1 to 4 inches reported, generally along and north of I-69. Locations across southeast Saginaw and southwest Tuscola counties saw the heaviest rain, just over 4 inches which caused significant flooding, resulting in at least 4.5 million dollars of damage. Numerous roads around Frankenmuth were flooded, but most of the road washouts and damage occurred across the county line in southwest Tuscola county.

Persistent strong north to east winds and extremely high river levels along the St. Clair River caused numerous roads and buildings to be flooded in Algonac and Harsens Island. The water level at Algonac peaked at 60 inches above LWD on May 9th around 230 PM LST.

A MCS tracked east-northeast from east-central MO/central IL Wednesday evening (May 22) through the IWX CWA early Thursday morning (May 23). Widespread wind gusts of 50-60 mph, with embedded channeled microburst gusts in excess of 70 mph, occurred with associated bowing segments.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported a one foot diameter tree was blown down onto a car.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported trees uprooted and blown over with some power lines down.

Numerous roads around Frankenmuth were flooded, but most of the road washouts and damage occurred across the county line in southwest Tuscola county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported  blown down.

In Kent county alone over 280,000 people lost power.  Over a hundred thousand people lost power across Kalamazoo county.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Wind gusts up to around 60 mph downed tree limbs and power lines and resulted in widespread power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: On Thursday March 14, 2019 three rounds of thunderstorms combined to drop approximately 1.5 inches of rain on much of Newaygo County. In addition, the ground was frozen and approximately 4 inches of snow water equivalent was contained in the snowpack. About 2.5 inches of this snow water melted and joined the rainfall runoff. ||These 3 factors all resulted in rapid and significant flooding across parts of the county that resulted in more than 50 homes and 9 businesses flooded, as well as the closure of more than 100 roads and the complete washout of more than 30 roads. A series of private dams on Penoyer Creek were also damaged. In addition, in the days after the storm, minor flooding developed along the Muskegon River that resulted in the flooding of an additional 105 homes. Damages from this storm across the county were more than $1.7 Million.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The combination of rain and snowmelt resulted in flooding and closure of more than a hundred roads.  30 roads were completely washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Arctic air flooding over the Upper Great Lakes supported moderate lake effect snow over portions of west and north central Upper Michigan from the 17th into the morning of the 18th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The station 11 miles southwest of Munising measured nearly a foot of snow in 36 hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Iron Mountain/Norway area reported a glaze of ice from freezing rain on decks, sidewalks and streets during the evening of the 28th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report from Rock of light icing from freezing rain on decks, sidewalks and secondary roads.

The NWS Marquette office in Negaunee Township measured 7 inches in the 12-hour period ending on the evening of the 30th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A narrow line of thunderstorms produced intense rainfall rates, with 3 to 6 inches of rain occurring over eastern Oakland and western Macomb Counties. M-59 was closed due to flooding northeast of Troy, along with Square Lake and John R roads.  In addition, cars were flooded and stuck on 19 mile and Mound roads. Numerous roads were also reported flooded throughout Sterling Heights and Clinton Township.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flood waters took several hours to recede.

On February 6, 2019 an ice jam formed on the Grand River in Portland. Approximately 50 residents were evacuated from their homes along Water Street in downtown Portland. 2 days later, on February 8, the ice jam shifted and thickened, causing additional flooding. Many businesses along Kent Street were flooded, and residents along Canal and Market streets were evacuated. The ice jam held for more than 3 weeks before finally melting and shifting downstream. Some homes on Water Street experienced continuous flooding for most of this 3 week period. The flooding caused approximately $200,000 damage to public facilities alone. This total does not include the damage to private homes and businesses from the flood.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An ice jam formed and held in Portland for three weeks, resulting in significant flooding and around 200,000 dollars in damage to public facilities.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two periods of freezing rain from February 5th through February 7th resulted in significant ice accumulation on the order of a half to three quarters of an inch across portions of central lower Michigan.  This resulted in thousands of downed trees, limbs and power lines.  Approximately one hundred and fifty thousand people lost power.  |Schools in the area were closed for days.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A half to three quarters of an inch of freezing rain resulted in numerous downed trees, limbs, power lines and widespread power outages.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A MCS tracked east-northeast from east-central MO/central IL Wednesday evening (May 22) through the IWX CWA early Thursday morning (May 23). Widespread wind gusts of 50-60 mph, with embedded channeled microburst gusts in excess of 70 mph, occurred with associated bowing segments.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Local media reported trees and power lines down across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A MCS tracked east-northeast from east-central MO/central IL Wednesday evening (May 22) through the IWX CWA early Thursday morning (May 23). Widespread wind gusts of 50-60 mph, with embedded channeled microburst gusts in excess of 70 mph, occurred with associated bowing segments.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trained spotters reported several healthy large trees uprooted or snapped, ranging from one to two feet in diameter.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported one inch diameter hail.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and power lines were reported blown down in several locations across the county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy rain with thunderstorms produced 2 to 4 inches of rain in about a 4 hour window across the I-94 corridor. This amount of rain in a short period caused flash flooding across parts of Wayne County, with the Dearborn Heights area being hardest hit. About 5000 homes experienced basement flooding, with 1000 homes or so suffering major flood damage.  Several road closures occurred or were rendered impassable as  many cars were stalled out in the high water over the roadways.
A storm system tracking from the Central Plains through Lower Michigan dumped heavy snow across much of the Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter east of Cusino Lake measured 15 inches of snow in less than 24 hours.  Schools were closed in northern Schoolcraft County on the 2nd in the aftermath of the snowstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system tracking from the Central Plains through Lower Michigan dumped heavy snow across much of the Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers across much of northern Houghton County measured between 6 and 7 inches of snow in less than 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms became severe at a few locations across southern lower Michigan and produced hail of up to an inch to inch and a quarter in diameter.  An isolated measured high wind gust of 67 mph was recorded at South Haven airport but no significant wind damage was reported anywhere in southern Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail stones of an inch to inch and a quarter were measured in Charlotte.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Scattered thunderstorms became severe at a few locations across southern lower Michigan and produced hail of up to an inch to inch and a quarter in diameter.  An isolated measured high wind gust of 67 mph was recorded at South Haven airport but no significant wind damage was reported anywhere in southern Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 67 mph peak wind gust was measured at South Haven Regional Airport.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure moved from Iowa to lower Michigan. Snow occurred north of the track of the low, primarily across eastern upper Michigan. Snowfall was enhanced by southerly winds off of Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, primarily into Mackinac County. Curtis picked up 14 inches of snowfall on the 12th, while Hessel received 12 inches.

Low pressure moved from Iowa to lower Michigan. Snow occurred north of the track of the low, primarily across eastern upper Michigan. Snowfall was enhanced by southerly winds off of Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, primarily into Mackinac County. Curtis picked up 14 inches of snowfall on the 12th, while Hessel received 12 inches.

Cold west winds blowing across northern Lake Michigan produced lake effect snow in northern lower Michigan. A narrow band of heavy lake effect impacted the tip of lower Michigan, including parts of Emmet and Cheboygan Counties. The Aloha area topped out at about 13 inches of new snow.

A strong and complex low pressure system crossed the southern Great Lakes on the 30th. In northern lower Michigan, most of this precipitation fell as rain, though there was quick transition to snow on the morning of the 30th, along with briefly heavy snowfall rates. The most substantial wintry precipitation was in eastern upper Michigan, with significant accumulations of snow and freezing rain in some areas. Curtis had around 10 inches of snowfall by the evening of the 30th. Meanwhile, some interior sections of western and central Chippewa County likely had over half an inch of ice accumulation. Numerous trees were downed, blocking roadways and causing power outages.
Thunderstorms developed north of an incoming warm front on the night of the 24th. The strongest storms produced hail.

The sudden relaxation of a gusty east wind, and quick transition to a northwest wind, resulted in a seiche on Lake Michigan. With very high water levels already in place on all of the Great Lakes, localized flooding developed.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Water entered some of the historic fishing shanties in the Fishtown section of Leland. Sandbags and other methods were deployed to attempt to keep the water out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Remnants of overnight MCS moved across the area during the day with occasional strong storms during peak heating. This activity left behind remnant outflows which focused late afternoon/evening storms across southern portions of the area. Additional storms developed along and just ahead of a cold front Tuesday evening into the early overnight hours.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported a tree was uprooted and blocking a road. Several other reports of large tree limbs being blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front triggered several severe thunderstorms producing both wind and hail, with Oakland county being hit the hardest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Multiple trees reported blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front triggered several severe thunderstorms producing both wind and hail, with Oakland county being hit the hardest.
An area of snow and gusty winds created difficult travel conditions during the morning hours of December 31st. Snow totals of 2 to 5 inches and wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow and blowing snow, with temperatures falling into the 20s, led to ice and snow covered roads during the morning hours of December 31st. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 2 and 4 inches. This in combination with west winds gusting as high as 50 mph led to reduced visibilities and difficult travel during this time. There were numerous reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of snow and gusty winds created difficult travel conditions during the morning hours of December 31st. Snow totals of 2 to 5 inches and wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow and blowing snow, with temperatures falling into the 20s, led to ice and snow covered roads during the morning hours of December 31st. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 2 and 3 inches. This in combination with west winds gusting as high as 50 mph led to reduced visibilities and difficult travel during this time. There were numerous reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A 56 knot peak wind gust was measured at the South Haven GLERL site.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that a large tree was blown down near the intersection of 84th street and Alden Nash road.

This in combination with west winds gusting as high as 50 mph led to reduced visibilities and difficult travel during this time. There were numerous reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow and blowing snow, with temperatures falling into the 20s, led to ice and snow covered roads during the morning hours of December 31st. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 2 and 5 inches. This in combination with west winds gusting as high as 50 mph led to reduced visibilities and difficult travel during this time. There were numerous reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An area of snow and gusty winds created difficult travel conditions during the morning hours of December 31st. Snow totals of 2 to 5 inches and wind gusts of 40 to 50 mph were common.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snow and blowing snow, with temperatures falling into the 20s, led to ice and snow covered roads during the morning hours of December 31st. Total snow accumulations across the county generally ranged between 2 and 4 inches. This in combination with west winds gusting as high as 50 mph led to reduced visibilities and difficult travel during this time. There were numerous reports of accidents and slide-offs across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest to north winds produced high waves and elevated water levels along the northwest lower Michigan coastline. With Great Lakes water levels at near-record levels, significant coastal flooding and beach erosion resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe beach erosion threatened to destroy a home several miles north of Frankfort.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A power pole was uprooted and tree limbs were blown down west of Clarksville.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several power poles and trees were blown down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A trained spotter reported that several trees were blown down near the intersection of Wyman and Deaner roads.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Severe storms produced scattered pockets of damaging wind gusts in the form of downed trees, tree limbs, and several power poles and power lines that were downed.  In addition a NWS storm survey confirmed that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county and resulted in extensive damage to a few barns and some tree damage. There were no injuries or fatalities.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A National Weather Service storm survey found that an EF-0 tornado struck southern Barry county.  The tornado damage path began on Barryville Road about one |quarter mile south of Cloverdale Road and ended on Marshall Road about a quarter mile south of Maple Grove Road. Three barns on one farm were damaged just southeast of the intersection of Barryville and Cloverdale Road and a telephone pole was blown down a few hundred feet northeast of the barns. About a dozen trees were|snapped or uprooted along the path of the tornado.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest to north winds produced high waves and elevated water levels along the northwest lower Michigan coastline. With Great Lakes water levels at near-record levels, significant coastal flooding and beach erosion resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Peninsula Drive was closed between McKinley and Wilson Roads due to coastal flooding and beach erosion. The east end of Marina Drive in Traverse City was also closed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest to north winds produced high waves and elevated water levels along the northwest lower Michigan coastline. With Great Lakes water levels at near-record levels, significant coastal flooding and beach erosion resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The parking lot of the Grand Traverse Yacht Club was flooded.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northerly to easterly winds resulted in another round of substantial coastal flooding and beach erosion, this time on both Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, for the 21st into the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A portion of M-185 on Mackinac Island was washed out.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Runoff from heavy rains of one to three inches over the weekend of 5/18-5/19 caused minor flooding of the Escanaba River at Humboldt and the Sturgeon River at Alston on the 20th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Minor flooding occurred at the Middle Branch of Escanaba River at Humboldt and caused water to flow over County Road FX for a few hours during the afternoon of the 20th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifting toward Saginaw Bay during the day caused scattered severe thunderstorms producing mostly wind damage north of the I-69 corridor. A weak tornado also developed near Marlette.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A weak tornado touched down and tracked southeast, with peak winds estimated to be 80 mph. Trees were blown down and a barn destroyed. Large tree limbs were also brought down around one house. Otherwise, the track was confirmed via corn field crop damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifting toward Saginaw Bay during the day caused scattered severe thunderstorms producing mostly wind damage north of the I-69 corridor. A weak tornado also developed near Marlette.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported blown down.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple strong to severe thunderstorms crossed northern Lake Michigan and northern lower Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Several trees were downed. Some power lines near the Leland Library were downed by falling trees.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Multiple strong to severe thunderstorms crossed northern Lake Michigan and northern lower Michigan.
Strong northerly to easterly winds resulted in another round of substantial coastal flooding and beach erosion, this time on both Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, for the 21st into the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: On the Old Mission Peninsula, docks were washed out. Waves reached the parking lot at Haserot Beach.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northerly to easterly winds resulted in another round of substantial coastal flooding and beach erosion, this time on both Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, for the 21st into the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Extended period of flooding reported. Between Tawas City and Alabaster, dock planks and some trees were washed away. An estimated 20 feet of beach disappeared. The road leading to the lighthouse at Tawas Point State Park was flooded, and eventually covered in sand and rocks.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northerly to easterly winds resulted in another round of substantial coastal flooding and beach erosion, this time on both Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, for the 21st into the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A bike path in Alpena was flooded and covered in sand.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northerly to easterly winds resulted in another round of substantial coastal flooding and beach erosion, this time on both Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, for the 21st into the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Severe beach erosion occurred at Black River. The overlook at the end of East Main Street in Harrisville was damaged.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northerly to easterly winds resulted in another round of substantial coastal flooding and beach erosion, this time on both Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, for the 21st into the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Just west of Bayshore, a portion of the Little Traverse Wheelway Bike Path was destroyed.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Strong northerly to easterly winds resulted in another round of substantial coastal flooding and beach erosion, this time on both Lake Michigan and Lake Huron, for the 21st into the 22nd.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A parking lot next to Betsie Lake in Frankfort flooded. A large field of debris, including entire trees and large tree limbs, was deposited along the beach at Point Betsie Lighthouse.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Northwest to north winds produced high waves and elevated water levels along the northwest lower Michigan coastline. With Great Lakes water levels at near-record levels, significant coastal flooding and beach erosion resulted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Flooding covered a portion of Lakeshore Drive at 5th Avenue Beach in Manistee. In Parkdale Township, the beach eroded up to the foundation of several homes, and a number of trees were washed into the lake.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: A dock, boardwalk, and beach signage were destroyed in Parkdale Township.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Dozen trees reported blown down, along with damage to house porch and pool deck.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A warm front lifting toward Saginaw Bay during the day caused scattered severe thunderstorms producing mostly wind damage north of the I-69 corridor. A weak tornado also developed near Marlette.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees and wires reported down. A couple farm outbuildings suffered roof, door, and siding damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front triggered several severe thunderstorms producing both wind and hail, with Oakland county being hit the hardest.
A strong cold front triggered several severe thunderstorms producing both wind and hail, with Oakland county being hit the hardest.
A strong cold front triggered several severe thunderstorms producing both wind and hail, with Oakland county being hit the hardest.
A few thunderstorms developed on the afternoon of the 25th. One produced severe hail in eastern upper Michigan.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Hail covered the ground near Rudyard. The largest hailstones were the size of quarters.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through a moist and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report via social media of one inch diameter hail three miles east of Redridge.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through a moist and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A NWS employee reported a large tree uprooted with numerous downed branches near Silver Lake.  Time of the report was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through a moist and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report of a tree struck by lightning just northwest of Crystal Falls.  The tree was estimated to be three and a half feet in diameter and split in pieces. Time of the report was estimated via ENTLN lightning data.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong and complex low pressure system crossed the southern Great Lakes on the 30th. In northern lower Michigan, most of this precipitation fell as rain, though there was quick transition to snow on the morning of the 30th, along with briefly heavy snowfall rates. The most substantial wintry precipitation was in eastern upper Michigan, with significant accumulations of snow and freezing rain in some areas. Curtis had around 10 inches of snowfall by the evening of the 30th. Meanwhile, some interior sections of western and central Chippewa County likely had over half an inch of ice accumulation. Numerous trees were downed, blocking roadways and causing power outages.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a report of a tree down on a vehicle near the intersection of Woodlawn Lane and Tobin Lane northeast of Channing.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through a moist and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a police scanner report of a tree down blocking one lane of Highway US-45 north of Watersmeet.  The time of the report was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front moving through a moist and unstable air mass produced severe thunderstorms over portions of western Upper Michigan on the evening of the 24th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A poplar and spruce tree were reported down across the street of the Running Bear  Resort and from nearby trails.  Other trees were reported down, but were cleared off the road before being observed by reporter. Timing of the wind damage report was estimated from radar.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong cold front triggered several severe thunderstorms producing both wind and hail, with Oakland county being hit the hardest.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Numerous trees blown down. Damage reported to a pavilion.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Low pressure crossed the southern Great Lakes on the 1st. Light mixed wintry precipitation late in the evening of the 30th became heavier in the early morning hours of the 1st. This was mostly snow across eastern upper Michigan and far northern lower Michigan. As you went further south, sleet and freezing rain became more prevalent. Gladwin picked up about a quarter of an inch of ice. Further north, snow amounts of 6 to 8 inches were common in northern lower Michigan. Parts of eastern upper Michigan had far, far higher totals, with Gould City getting 28 inches of snow, and Engadine 20 inches. Winds gusted up to 45 mph, though the highest winds did not correspond to the heaviest snowfall. Still, travel was severely restricted due to falling and blowing snow. Finally, a few trees were downed by wind near Rogers City.

A storm system tracking from the Central Plains through Lower Michigan dumped heavy snow across much of the Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The spotter northwest of Iron Mountain measured 10.5 inches of wet snow in approximately 24 hours.  Many schools delayed classes on the 2nd in the aftermath of the storm.  The observer in Norway reported a scotch pine tree uprooted in his driveway due to the weight of the heavy snow.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system tracking from the Central Plains through Lower Michigan dumped heavy snow across much of the Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report 9 miles south of Kenton of 10.5 inches of snow in approximately 24 hours.   Many schools delayed classes on the 2nd in the aftermath of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system tracking from the Central Plains through Lower Michigan dumped heavy snow across much of the Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters measured 24-hour snowfall amounts of 23 inches in Escanaba and 20 inches near Gladstone.  The awning of a pub on Ludington Street in Escanaba collapsed due to the weight of the snow.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system tracking from the Central Plains through Lower Michigan dumped heavy snow across much of the Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals over a 24-hour period included an estimated 20 inches near Daggett and nearly 14 inches in Spalding.  ||A day after the storm, 19 people had to be rescued from a cabin in Spalding Township on North Gable Road off of Highway M-69. There were 10 children and 9 adults stuck in the cabin. First responders from Meyer, Mellen and Cedarville Township Volunteer Fire Departments used a Polaris Ranger to reach the cabin and rescue the stranded people. |Menominee County Road Commission, Spalding Fire, Meyer Fire, Harris Fire, Cedarville Fire, MDNR conservation officers and Menominee County Sheriff deputies responded to the rescue.  Schools were closed throughout the county on the 2nd.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system tracking from the Central Plains through Lower Michigan dumped heavy snow across much of the Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Public 24-hour snowfall reports across the county included 18.5 inches at Munising, 17 inches at Wetmore and 14 inches at Eben Junction.  Schools delayed the start of classes on the 2nd due to the aftermath of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A moist flow of air ahead of a Plains low pressure system produced periods of light freezing rain over portions of central Upper Michigan from the afternoon of the 28th into the morning of the 29th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Light icing from freezing rain was reported from Gwinn to Marquette to Ishpeming from the evening of the 28th into the morning of the 29th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals over a 24-hour period included an estimated 26 inches at Steuben and 24 inches at Blaney Park.  Schools were closed on the 2nd in the aftermath of the snowstorm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Cold west winds blowing across northern Lake Michigan produced lake effect snow in northern lower Michigan. A narrow band of heavy lake effect impacted the tip of lower Michigan, including parts of Emmet and Cheboygan Counties. The Aloha area topped out at about 13 inches of new snow.

Low pressure crossed the southern Great Lakes on the 1st. Light mixed wintry precipitation late in the evening of the 30th became heavier in the early morning hours of the 1st. This was mostly snow across eastern upper Michigan and far northern lower Michigan. As you went further south, sleet and freezing rain became more prevalent. Gladwin picked up about a quarter of an inch of ice. Further north, snow amounts of 6 to 8 inches were common in northern lower Michigan. Parts of eastern upper Michigan had far, far higher totals, with Gould City getting 28 inches of snow, and Engadine 20 inches. Winds gusted up to 45 mph, though the highest winds did not correspond to the heaviest snowfall. Still, travel was severely restricted due to falling and blowing snow. Finally, a few trees were downed by wind near Rogers City.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting across northern Lake Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals over an approximate 18-hour period included from 7 to 8 inches in Marquette to nearly 9 inches in Harvey.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting across northern Lake Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the morning of the 10th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals over a 24-hour period included 11 inches in Painesdale, nearly 10 inches in Twin Lakes and 8 inches in Houghton.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A low pressure system lifting across northern Lake Michigan produced moderate to heavy snow over portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the 9th into the morning of the 10th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system tracking from the Central Plains through Lower Michigan dumped heavy snow across much of the Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Snowfall totals over a 24-hour period generally ranged from 12 to 16 inches from  Marquette and Harvey to National Mine.  Schools were closed on the 2nd in the aftermath of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system originating over the southern Plains lifted through Lower Michigan and dumped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 30th into early on the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a social media report of an estimated seven inches of snow in 12 hours in Ontonagon.  Observers near Mass City and Paulding respectively measured 12 inches and 9.4 inches of snow in 24 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system in the Plains states moved across the southern Great Lakes region bringing a mix of moderate to heavy snow.  There was also a period of freezing rain before precipitation changed over to snow and up to around a quarter of an inch of freezing rain accumulation was reported across portions of Mason and Lake counties. Ten to 12 inches of snow also fell across much of Mason and Lake counties which resulted in hazardous travel conditions and numerous power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Twelve inches of snow was reported in Walhalla and Custer.  There were also some power outages due to the weight of snow and freezing rain that also fell and a quarter of an inch of freezing rain was reported by the public near Custer.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: An upper level low pressure system in the Plains states moved across the southern Great Lakes region bringing a mix of moderate to heavy snow.  There was also a period of freezing rain before precipitation changed over to snow and up to around a quarter of an inch of freezing rain accumulation was reported across portions of Mason and Lake counties. Ten to 12 inches of snow also fell across much of Mason and Lake counties which resulted in hazardous travel conditions and numerous power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that ten to twelve inches of snow fell across much of Lake county.  There were also numerous power outages due to the weight of snow and freezing rain that also fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system originating over the southern Plains lifted through Lower Michigan and dumped widespread heavy snow across Upper Michigan from the 30th into early on the 31st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The station in Spalding measured 7.5 inches of wet snow in less than 12 hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A storm system tracking from the Central Plains through Lower Michigan dumped heavy snow across much of the Upper Michigan on the 1st.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Paulding through Bergland to Silver City measured 8 to 11 inches of snow in 12 hours or less. Many schools were closed on the 2nd in the aftermath of the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate to heavy lake effect snow occurred across portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th through the morning of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 12 to 18 inches of lake effect snow fell over portions of southern Schoolcraft County mainly from Steuben to Germfask in an approximate 24-hour period.  The highest observed total was near Steuben where an estimated 18 inches of snow fell.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A southerly flow of relatively cold air across Lake Michigan generated heavy lake enhanced snow into portions of Schoolcraft and Luce counties on the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 12 inches of wet, heavy lake enhanced snow fell at the Cobblestone Bar & Grill in McMillan in approximately nine hours. An estimated seven inches of snow fell in Newberry with numerous traffic accidents reported.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow was observed over the northwest winds snow belts of Upper Michigan on the 5th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A spotter at Chassell estimated five inches of lake effect snow in six hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Moderate lake effect snow was observed over the northwest winds snow belts of Upper Michigan on the 5th.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a public report near Cusino Lake of an estimated eight inches of lake effect snow in five hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A strong arctic cold front produced a widespread snow event on November 11th in southern Michigan. This then transitioned to heavy lake effect showers late on November 11th into November 12th as unseasonably cold air overspread the Great Lakes region. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 5 and 10 inches, though locally heavier amounts were common in areas that received heavy lake effect snow.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Widespread light to moderate snow developed during the early morning hours of November 11th and continued through the day. This then transitioned to heavy lake effect snow showers late on November 11th into the morning hours of November 12th. Total snow accumulations generally ranged between 8 and 12 inches, though some areas in central Cass County received amounts up to 18 inches where a heavy lake effect snow band set up. Diamond Lake received 15.0 inches of snow. Snowfall rates of 2-3 inches per hour were also common with whiteout conditions, which made for very difficult travel. Roads being snow covered, and reduced visibilities, led to a few accidents and slide-offs, along with numerous school delays and closings across the region.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening storm system tracking from the Central Plains across northern Lower Michigan snarled holiday traffic by dumping moderate to heavy snow across much of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 27th, the day before Thanksgiving.  The dense heavy snow combined with strong northeast to east winds gusting from 35 mph to more than 50 mph at times to cause downed trees and power poles across much of Upper Michigan.  Widespread power outages were reported across much of Upper Michigan affecting thousands of customers, and some residences remained without power for several days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The higher terrain of Marquette measured between 12 and 16 inches of snowfall during the storm event.  The National Weather Service in Negaunee Township measured just over 16 inches of snow during the event with 3 inches of liquid water content.  The dense, heavy snow combining with northerly wind gusts of 35 to 40 mph at times caused damage to trees and power lines across the county.  UPPCO reported that the winds, weight of the snow and falling trees snapped 40 power poles, which had to be replaced.  UPPCO also reported that 12,000 customers or about 20 percent of their customer base lost power at least once during the event.  Around 150 workers spent approximately 15,000 hours repairing the damage to power lines, and crew were dispatched to 2100 locations to make repairs. Many businesses were closed on the 27th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Heavy lake effect snow developed into parts of northwest lower Michigan, including the Traverse City area. Snowfall rates of 1 to 2 inches per hour occurred in the stronger lake effect snow bands on the night of the 7th. By morning of the 8th, 16 inches of new snow had fallen in Fife Lake, 12 inches in Mancelona, 11 inches in Kalkaska, and 9 inches near Greilickville.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a social media report near Skanee of an estimated eight inches of lake effect snow in nine hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long northerly fetch of Arctic air across Lake Superior generated intense lake enhanced snow over portions of north central Upper Michigan on the 7th.  More than a foot of snow fell at some locations.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Spotters measured between 10 and 18 inches of snowfall over eastern Marquette County on the 7th.  Totals included nearly 10 inches in the city of Marquette, 12 inches in Harvey, 14 inches in Skandia and 18 inches at Shot Point.  The Marquette City Police urged people to avoid travel unless absolutely necessary on the 7th as road conditions were extremely snow-covered and slippery.  Northern Michigan University and North Star Montessori Academy closed by early afternoon due to the heavy snow and hazardous road conditions.

A clipper-type low pressure system brought mainly light snow to the region on the 13th. However, the snow was substantially enhanced downwind of Lake Michigan. Southerly winds focused this lake enhancement in far western Mackinac County in eastern upper Michigan. By late afternoon on the 13th, Curtis had picked up 11 inches of new snow.

Low pressure intensified as it lifted northeast across the western and northern Great Lakes on the day before Thanksgiving. This brought heavy snow to a portion of eastern upper Michigan. Better snowfall accumulations were largely confined to western Chippewa County, where Hulbert and Eckerman checked in with 8 to 12 inches of snow by afternoon on the 27th. Winds gusted up to 40 mph at times, resulting in considerable blowing and drifting snow, and impacting travel during the pre-holiday period.
A southerly flow of relatively cold air across Lake Michigan generated heavy lake enhanced snow into portions of Schoolcraft and Luce counties on the 13th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated six to eight inches of wet, heavy lake enhanced snow fell from Manistique through Gulliver to Blaney Park in approximately nine hours.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: An estimated 12 inches of wet, heavy lake enhanced snow fell at Seney in approximately nine hours.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long duration heavy snow event impacted southeast Michigan on Veterans day 2019. The storm peaked during the noon/early afternoon time-frame when 1 per hour snowfall occurred over the western and northern suburbs of Detroit. Meanwhile, northerly flow off of Lake Huron allowed for lake-enhanced snowfall rates over the Thumb, especially over areas on the northern and eastern shorelines with some locations seeing over a foot of snow.  In general, most of southeast Michigan saw between 6-12 inches of snow, with less than 6 inches over Tri-Cities region and near the southern Michigan border. ||Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:|Lexington... 14.0 inches|Port Huron... 14.0 inches|Bad Axe... 12.0 inches|Ann Arbor... 11.0 inches|Shelby Township... 11.0 inches|Sterling Heights... 10.0 inches|Wixom... 10.0 inches|Elba... 9.5  inches|Romulus (Detroit Metro)... 9.2 inches|Flint Bishop Airport... 9.0 inches|Pinckney... 8.2 inches|Caro... 7.5 inches.

An early season snowstorm and lake effect snow event impacted the western Great Lakes from November 11th to Tuesday November 12th. Snow totals measured in feet in the lake effect snow belts. Some locations picked up 12 to 18 inches of snow in just 12 hours!  Record breaking cold temperatures followed on Tuesday enabling wind chills to drop into the single digits.  While such snow totals and cold temperatures are not uncommon in Michigan during the winter months, experiencing such conditions in early November is unusual.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Up to around a foot of snow was reported across portions of Mason county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening storm system tracking from the Central Plains across northern Lower Michigan snarled holiday traffic by dumping moderate to heavy snow across much of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 27th, the day before Thanksgiving.  The dense heavy snow combined with strong northeast to east winds gusting from 35 mph to more than 50 mph at times to cause downed trees and power poles across much of Upper Michigan.  Widespread power outages were reported across much of Upper Michigan affecting thousands of customers, and some residences remained without power for several days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers from Ironwood and Bessemer to 10 miles west of Watersmeet measured between 8 and 10 inches of heavy lake enhanced snow.  The wet, heavy snow combined with northeast winds gusting to 35 to 40 mph at times caused damage to trees and power lines which blocked some secondary roads and snowmobile trails.  Schools and a few businesses closed on the 27th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening storm system tracking from the Central Plains across northern Lower Michigan snarled holiday traffic by dumping moderate to heavy snow across much of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 27th, the day before Thanksgiving.  The dense heavy snow combined with strong northeast to east winds gusting from 35 mph to more than 50 mph at times to cause downed trees and power poles across much of Upper Michigan.  Widespread power outages were reported across much of Upper Michigan affecting thousands of customers, and some residences remained without power for several days after the storm.

The wet, heavy snow combined with north to northeast winds gusting near 50 mph at times caused damage to trees and power lines which blocked some secondary roads and snowmobile trails.  Many businesses closed on the 27th due to the storm, and afternoon classes were cancelled at Michigan Technological University.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening storm system tracking from the Central Plains across northern Lower Michigan snarled holiday traffic by dumping moderate to heavy snow across much of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 27th, the day before Thanksgiving.  The dense heavy snow combined with strong northeast to east winds gusting from 35 mph to more than 50 mph at times to cause downed trees and power poles across much of Upper Michigan.  Widespread power outages were reported across much of Upper Michigan affecting thousands of customers, and some residences remained without power for several days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Observers at Herman and Watton measured between nine and ten inches of dense lake enhanced snow on the 27th.  The wet, heavy snow combined with northeast winds gusting to 40 to 50 mph at times caused damage to trees and power lines which blocked some secondary roads and snowmobile trails.  Baraga County Offices were closed on the 27th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A long duration heavy snow event impacted southeast Michigan on Veterans day 2019. The storm peaked during the noon/early afternoon time-frame when 1 per hour snowfall occurred over the western and northern suburbs of Detroit. Meanwhile, northerly flow off of Lake Huron allowed for lake-enhanced snowfall rates over the Thumb, especially over areas on the northern and eastern shorelines with some locations seeing over a foot of snow.  In general, most of southeast Michigan saw between 6-12 inches of snow, with less than 6 inches over Tri-Cities region and near the southern Michigan border. ||Here are some of the higher snowfall totals reported:|Lexington... 14.0 inches|Port Huron... 14.0 inches|Bad Axe... 12.0 inches|Ann Arbor... 11.0 inches|Shelby Township... 11.0 inches|Sterling Heights... 10.0 inches|Wixom... 10.0 inches|Elba... 9.5  inches|Romulus (Detroit Metro)... 9.2 inches|Flint Bishop Airport... 9.0 inches|Pinckney... 8.2 inches|Caro... 7.5 inches.

An early season snowstorm and lake effect snow event impacted the western Great Lakes from November 11th to Tuesday November 12th. Snow totals measured in feet in the lake effect snow belts. Some locations picked up 12 to 18 inches of snow in just 12 hours!  Record breaking cold temperatures followed on Tuesday enabling wind chills to drop into the single digits.  While such snow totals and cold temperatures are not uncommon in Michigan during the winter months, experiencing such conditions in early November is unusual.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Eight to 12 inches of snow fell across Oceana county with relatively highest amounts across northern Oceana county.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening storm system tracking from the Central Plains across northern Lower Michigan snarled holiday traffic by dumping moderate to heavy snow across much of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 27th, the day before Thanksgiving.  The dense heavy snow combined with strong northeast to east winds gusting from 35 mph to more than 50 mph at times to cause downed trees and power poles across much of Upper Michigan.  Widespread power outages were reported across much of Upper Michigan affecting thousands of customers, and some residences remained without power for several days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The observer 11 miles southwest of Munising measured 12 inches of storm total snowfall.  The dense, heavy snow combined with northerly winds gusting to 40 to 50 mph at times caused damage to trees and power lines and widespread power outages throughout the region.  The storm forced many businesses to close on the 27th.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening storm system tracking from the Central Plains across northern Lower Michigan snarled holiday traffic by dumping moderate to heavy snow across much of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 27th, the day before Thanksgiving.  The dense heavy snow combined with strong northeast to east winds gusting from 35 mph to more than 50 mph at times to cause downed trees and power poles across much of Upper Michigan.  Widespread power outages were reported across much of Upper Michigan affecting thousands of customers, and some residences remained without power for several days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated total of 10 inches of snow in approximately six hours.  The combination of dense, heavy and northerly winds gusting to 40 to 45 mph caused damage to trees and power lines during the storm.  There was an estimated that nearly 30 percent of residences in the county lost power during the storm.  Many businesses were closed on the 27th due to the storm.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was an estimated six inches of wet, heavy snow that fell in 12 hours over northern portions of Dickinson County.  The combination of the dense snow and northerly winds gusting to 40 to 45 mph at times caused damage to trees and power lines.  There was an estimate that nearly 30 percent of the residences in the county lost power during the storm. Many businesses were closed on the 27th due to the storm.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Extremely heavy lake effect snow fell on portions of northwest lower Michigan. North-northwest to north winds focused the heaviest bands over coastal counties, Leelanau in particular. The heavier snow got going very early in the morning of the 11th; by early afternoon, Burdickville in Leelanau County was already at 15 inches, while Maple City and Suttons Bay were at 6 to 9 inches. Frankfort was at 10 inches of snow by late afternoon, and Empire was at 18 inches. Manistee reached 8 inches of snow on the evening of the 11th, with whiteout conditions reported. By the time the snow diminished by midday on the 12th, the Lake Leelanau area had picked up an impressive 32 inches of total snowfall. Empire received about 30 inches, and Beulah 24 inches. Interlochen checked in with 13 inches.

Widespread lakeshore flooding from record high water levels of the Great Lakes and periodic strong onshore flow occurred from late April 2019 to November 2019. Extensive erosion and property damage occurred, with monetary values in the millions. The widespread flooding ended at the end of November when the Great Lakes reached winter seasonal minimum water levels.
