A deepening storm system tracking from the Central Plains across northern Lower Michigan snarled holiday traffic by dumping moderate to heavy snow across much of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 27th, the day before Thanksgiving.  The dense heavy snow combined with strong northeast to east winds gusting from 35 mph to more than 50 mph at times to cause downed trees and power poles across much of Upper Michigan.  Widespread power outages were reported across much of Upper Michigan affecting thousands of customers, and some residences remained without power for several days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northerly storm force winds over 50 knots whipped up waves as high as 15 to 20 feet over Lake Superior on the 27th.  The high waves caused extensive lakeshore flooding and erosion in Marquette, especially along Lakeshore Boulevard where a car became stranded in water after driving through road closure barriers.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening storm system tracking from the Central Plains across northern Lower Michigan snarled holiday traffic by dumping moderate to heavy snow across much of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 27th, the day before Thanksgiving.  The dense heavy snow combined with strong northeast to east winds gusting from 35 mph to more than 50 mph at times to cause downed trees and power poles across much of Upper Michigan.  Widespread power outages were reported across much of Upper Michigan affecting thousands of customers, and some residences remained without power for several days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Northerly storm force winds over 50 knots whipped up waves as high as 15 to 20 feet over Lake Superior on the 27th. The high waves caused extensive lakeshore flooding and erosion near Eagle Harbor, where portions of Highway M-26 were closed due to water over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A deepening storm system tracking from the Central Plains across northern Lower Michigan snarled holiday traffic by dumping moderate to heavy snow across much of west and north central Upper Michigan on the 27th, the day before Thanksgiving.  The dense heavy snow combined with strong northeast to east winds gusting from 35 mph to more than 50 mph at times to cause downed trees and power poles across much of Upper Michigan.  Widespread power outages were reported across much of Upper Michigan affecting thousands of customers, and some residences remained without power for several days after the storm.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: East to northeast storm force winds over 50 knots whipped up waves as high as 7 to 10 feet over the Bay of Green Bay on the 27th. The high waves caused extensive lakeshore flooding and erosion from Menominee to ten miles north.  A NWS employee driving along Highway M-35 reported extensive flooding of properties along the highway and evidence of water going over the road.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A negatively tilted trough, combined with a 130 knot jet streak forced the rapid development and intensification of seasonably deep low pressure. The low tracked across  northeastern Illinois and then into central Lake Michigan. While some stronger wind gusts were noted along a cold front, pockets of damaging winds occurred behind the front with 50 to 60 mph wind gusts common, resulting in power outages, trees and power lines down and some minor structure damage.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees, tree limbs, power lines and poles were all reported down in spots across the county. The Benton Harbor Automated Surface Observation System recorded a 63 mph wind gust, with a mesonet site in Benton Heights recording a 62 mph wind gust.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Two severe thunderstorms producing wind damage developed ahead of a strong cold front. Winds behind the cold front were also very strong, reaching 55-60 mph south of eight Mile Road. Ann Arbor, Detroit Metro, and city airport of Detroit all reported a peak wind gust of 58 mph, while Adrian and Ypsilanti airports reported 55 mph and 56 mph. Despite these stronger winds, tree damage and power outages were limited.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Trees reported blown down.

Moderate to heavy lake effect snow occurred across portions of west and central Upper Michigan from the evening of the 10th through the morning of the 12th.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There was a social media report of an estimated 16 inches of snow in approximately 27 hours at Forest Lake.  The spotter ten miles south of Grand Marais measured 11 inches of snow in 24 hours.  Two inch per hour snowfall rates were reported in Rumely during the event.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Thunderstorms developed  developed near Lake St. Clair and produced one inch hail and strong wind gusts.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Power lines were reported blown down by the wind.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A wedge of instability built in across southern Michigan throughout the late morning and afternoon and was the source of numerous strong thunderstorms, many of which produced both severe wind gusts to 60 mph and hail up to 1.25 inches for locations along the I-69 corridor and south down to the Ohio border. Most of the severe hail was confined to Lenawee and Monroe Counties, but pea (1/4) to penny (3/4) sized hail was observed at multiple locations across southeast Michigan. Additionally, a line of thunderstorms extending north from Milan and Ann Arbor up to Flint pushed east throughout the afternoon and produced sporadic 60 mph wind gusts, resulting in scattered tree damage, isolated building damage, and power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Four inch diameter tree limbs reported down.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Easterly winds of 15 to 30 mph over western Lake Erie lead to some lakeshore flooding. The water level at Toledo peaked at 76.1 inches above LWD during the evening of June 8th, with Fermi and Gibraltor peaking around 72 inches above LWD.

Thunderstorms caused easterly winds to reach 30 mph or greater, which caused a rapid rise in water levels over western Lake Erie and the Detroit River. Gibraltar's water level peaked at 81.1 inches above chart datum just before midnight, with Fermi and Toledo's water levels holding around 76 inches.

Thunderstorms caused easterly winds to reach 30 mph or greater, which caused a rapid rise in water levels over western Lake Erie and the Detroit River. Gibraltar's water level peaked at 81.1 inches above chart datum just before midnight, with Fermi and Toledo's water levels holding around 76 inches.

A wedge of instability built in across southern Michigan throughout the late morning and afternoon and was the source of numerous strong thunderstorms, many of which produced both severe wind gusts to 60 mph and hail up to 1.25 inches for locations along the I-69 corridor and south down to the Ohio border. Most of the severe hail was confined to Lenawee and Monroe Counties, but pea (1/4) to penny (3/4) sized hail was observed at multiple locations across southeast Michigan. Additionally, a line of thunderstorms extending north from Milan and Ann Arbor up to Flint pushed east throughout the afternoon and produced sporadic 60 mph wind gusts, resulting in scattered tree damage, isolated building damage, and power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: A tree was reported down.

Most of the severe hail was confined to Lenawee and Monroe Counties, but pea (1/4) to penny (3/4) sized hail was observed at multiple locations across southeast Michigan. Additionally, a line of thunderstorms extending north from Milan and Ann Arbor up to Flint pushed east throughout the afternoon and produced sporadic 60 mph wind gusts, resulting in scattered tree damage, isolated building damage, and power outages.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: Large tree limbs were reported down.

Easterly winds of 15 to 30 mph over western Lake Erie lead to some lakeshore flooding. The water level at Toledo peaked at 76.1 inches above LWD during the evening of June 8th, with Fermi and Gibraltor peaking around 72 inches above LWD.

A wedge of instability built in across southern Michigan throughout the late morning and afternoon and was the source of numerous strong thunderstorms, many of which produced both severe wind gusts to 60 mph and hail up to 1.25 inches for locations along the I-69 corridor and south down to the Ohio border. Most of the severe hail was confined to Lenawee and Monroe Counties, but pea (1/4) to penny (3/4) sized hail was observed at multiple locations across southeast Michigan. A quasi linear convective system (QLCS) produced wind damage along a fifty mile long and a half to 5 mile swath that cut through parts of downtown Grand Rapids.  Significant wind damage was observed within to just east of the city.  The most intense damage occurred at Belknap apartments in downtown Grand Rapids where two thirds of the roof was ripped off of the three story complex. There was also scattered tree damage and a few shingles missing from houses near the apartment complex. A microburst containing winds of up to around 100 mph caused the damage. Additional significant damage was noted about 1.5 miles east of the Belknap apartments where several buildings incurred significant damage.  Hundreds of trees were either snapped off or uprooted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: There were two houses that sustained damage in the form of broken windows and lost roofing and shingle damage.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quasi linear convective system (QLCS) produced wind damage along a fifty mile long and a half to 5 mile swath that cut through parts of downtown Grand Rapids.  Significant wind damage was observed within to just east of the city.  The most intense damage occurred at Belknap apartments in downtown Grand Rapids where two thirds of the roof was ripped off of the three story complex. There was also scattered tree damage and a few shingles missing from houses near the apartment complex. A microburst containing winds of up to around 100 mph caused the damage. Additional significant damage was noted about 1.5 miles east of the Belknap apartments where several buildings incurred significant damage.  Hundreds of trees were either snapped off or uprooted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: The public reported that a large barn was blown off it's foundation and there was minor damage to a small barn in the same area near Woodbury. Scattered wind damage was also noted from southeast of Lowell to Lake Odessa in the form of scattered downed trees and limbs.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: Easterly winds of 30 to 40 MPH on April 11th lead to high water levels over the Western Lake Erie basin and large wave action, causing lakeshore flooding. The water level at Toledo peaked just above 90 inches above Low Water Daturm, while Fermi and Gibralter both peaked out around 78 inches during the afternoon hours. Residents were evacuated in Frenchtown Charter Township and Luna Pier, as homes were impacted with some homes under water.

EVENT_NARRATIVE: Apartment building on Fairview Ave NE just east of Division Street had roofed peeled off. Roof landed on homes immediately to the east of the apartment building.

The most intense damage occurred at Belknap apartments in downtown Grand Rapids where two thirds of the roof was ripped off of the three story complex. There was also scattered tree damage and a few shingles missing from houses near the apartment complex. A microburst containing winds of up to around 100 mph caused the damage. Additional significant damage was noted about 1.5 miles east of the Belknap apartments where several buildings incurred significant damage.  Hundreds of trees were either snapped off or uprooted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS storm surveys in eastern Kent county found that hundreds of trees were either snapped or uprooted across three distinct swaths near Ada and Forest Hills.  Some building damage occurred as a result of falling trees and many roads were blocked by downed trees and power lines.

EPISODE_NARRATIVE: A quasi linear convective system (QLCS) produced wind damage along a fifty mile long and a half to 5 mile swath that cut through parts of downtown Grand Rapids.  Significant wind damage was observed within to just east of the city.  The most intense damage occurred at Belknap apartments in downtown Grand Rapids where two thirds of the roof was ripped off of the three story complex. There was also scattered tree damage and a few shingles missing from houses near the apartment complex. A microburst containing winds of up to around 100 mph caused the damage. Additional significant damage was noted about 1.5 miles east of the Belknap apartments where several buildings incurred significant damage.  Hundreds of trees were either snapped off or uprooted.
EVENT_NARRATIVE: NWS storm surveys confirmed that a quasi linear convective system produced significant wind damage in and just east of Grand Rapids.  The survey team estimated that microbursts containing winds of up to 100 mph caused the damage.  Damage included significant roof damage to the Belknap apartment complex and significant damage in a subdivision a mile and a half east of Belknap apartments. Some building damage also occurred due to falling trees and many roads were blocked due to downed trees and power lines.

Residents were evacuated in Frenchtown Charter Township and Luna Pier, as homes were impacted with some homes under water.
An isolated severe storm produced wind damage in a small portion of Van Buren county.
